editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The pleasant history of the two angry women of Abington.
With the humorous mirth of Dick Coomes and Nicholas proverbs, two serving-men.
As it was lately played by the right honourable the Earl of Nottingham, lord high admiral his servants.
Imprinted at London for William Ferbrand, and are to be sold at his shop at the corner of Colman street near Loathbury. 1599.

div.head: The prologue.
div.p: Gentlemen, I come to ye like one that lacks and would borrow, but was loath to ask lest he should be denied: I would ask, but I would ask to obtain: oh would I knew that manner of asking: to beg were base, and to cooche low and to carry an humble show of entreaty, were too doglike that fawns on his master to get a bone from his trencher: out curre I cannot abide it, to put on the shape and habit of this new world's new found beggars, mistermed soldiers, as thus: sweet gentlemen, let a poor scholar implore and exerate, that you would make him rich in the possession of a mite of your favours, to keep him a true man in wit, and to pay for his lodging among the Muses: so God him help he is driven to a most low estate, 'tis not unknown what service of words he hath been at, he lost his limbs in a late conflict of flout, a brave repulse and a hot assault it was, he doth protest, as ever he saw since he knew what the report of a volley of testes were, he shall therefore desire you: a plague upon it, each beadle disdained, would whip him from your company. Well gentlemen, I cannot tell how to get your favours better than by desert: then the worse luck, or the worse wit or some what, for I shall not now deserve it. Welcome then, I commit myself to my fortunes, and your contents, contented to die, if your severe judgements shall judge me to be stung to death with the adder's hiss.

div.head: The pleasant comedy of the two angry women of Abington.
div.stage: Enter master Goursey and his wife, and master barns and his wife, with their two sons, and their two servants.

sp.speaker: Master Goursey.
sp.l: Good master barns, this entertain of yours,
So full of courtesy and rich delight,
Makes me misdoubt my poor ability,
In quittance of this friendly courtesy.

sp.speaker: Master Bar.
sp.l: O master Goursey, neighbour amity,
Is such aye well of high reckoned worth:
As for the attain of it, what would not I
Disburse, it is so precious in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Kind sir, near dwelling amity indeed,
Offers the heart's enquiry better view.
Then love that's seated in a farther soil,
As prospectives the nearer that they be,
Yield better judgement to the judging eye,
Things seen far off, are lessened in the eye,
When their true shape is seen being hard by.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: True sir, 'tis so, and truly I esteem,
Mere amity familiar neighbourhood,
The cousin germane unto wedded love.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Ay sir, there's surely some alliance twixt them,
For they have both the offspring from the heart,
Within the heart's blood ocean still are found,
Jewels of amity, and gems of love.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I master Goursey, I have in my time,
seen many shipwracks of true honesty,
But incident such dangers ever are,
To them that without compass sail so far,
Why what need men to swim when they may wade?
But leave this talk, enough of this is said,
And master Goursey, in good faith sir welcome:
And mistress Goursey, I am much in debt,
Unto your kindness that would visit me.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: O master Barnes, you put me but in mind,
Of that which I should say: 'tis we that are
Indebted to your kindness for this cheer:
Which debt that we may repay, I pray let's have,
Sometimes your company, at our homely house.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: That mistress Goursey you shall surely have,
He'll be a bold guest I warrant ye,
And boulder too with you than I would have him.

sp.speaker: M●s. Gou.
sp.l: How do ye mean he will be bold with me?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Why he will trouble you at home forsooth,
Often call in, and ask ye how ye do:
And sit and that with you all day till night,
And all night too if he might have his will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I wife indeed, I thank her for her kindness,
She hath made me much good cheer passing that way.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Passing well done of her, she is a kind wench,
I thank ye mistress Goursey for my husband,
And if it hap your husband come our way
A hunting, or such ordinary sports,
I'll do as much for yours, as you for mine.

sp.speaker: Master Gou
sp.l: Pray do forsooth, god's lord what means the woman,
She speaks it scornfully, i'faith I care not,
Things are well spoken, if they be well taken,
What mistress barns, is it not time to part?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: What's o'clock sirrah?

sp.speaker: Nicholas.
sp.l: 'Tis but new struck one.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I have some business in the town by three.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Till then let's walk into the orchard sir.
What can you play at tables?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What, shall we have a game?

sp.speaker: Master Gou.
sp.l: And if you please.

sp.speaker: M. Bar
sp.l: I'faith content, we'll spend an hour so:
Sirrah fetch the tables,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirrah Frank, whilst they are playing here,
We'll to the green to bowls.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Philip content, Coomes come hither sirrah,
When our father's part, call us upon the green,
Philip come, a rubber and so leave,

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: 'Sblood, I do not like the humour of these springas, they'll spend all their fathers' good at gamming ▪ but let them troll the bowls upon the green: he troll the bowls in the buttery, by the leave of God and master barns: and his men be good fellows so it is, if they be not let them go snick up.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: So set them down,
Mistress Goursey, how do you like this game?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Can ye play at it?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: A little sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Faith so can my wife.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why then master Barnes, and if you please,
Our wives shall try the quarrel twixt us two,
And we'll look on?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I am content, what woman will you play?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: I care not greatly.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Nor I, but that I think she'll play me false.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I'll see she shall not.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Nay sir, she will be sure you shall not see.
You of all men shall not mark her hand,
She hath such close conveyance in her play.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Is she so cunning grown, come, come, let's see.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Yea mistress Barnes, will ye not house your jests,
But let them roam abroad so carelessly?
Faith, if your jealous tongue utter another,
I'll cross ye with a jest, and ye were my mother,
Come shall we play?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar,
sp.l: Ay, what shall we play a game?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: A pound a game.

sp.speaker: M. Gou
sp.l: How wife?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Faith husband not a farthing less.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: It is too much, a shilling were good game.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: No, we'll be ill huswives once,
You have oft been ill husbands, let's alone.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wife, will you play so much?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I would be loath to be so frank a gamester
As mistress Goursey is, and yet for once,
I'll play a pound a game as well as she.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Go to, you'll have your will.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Come, there's my stake.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: And there's mine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Throw for the dice: ill luck they are yours.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Master Goursey, who says that gamings bad,
When such good angels walk twixt every cast?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: This is not noble sport, but royal play.

sp.speaker: M. Bar
sp.l: It must be so where royals walk so fast.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Play right I pray.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Why so I do.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Where stands your man?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: In his right place.

sp.speaker: M●s. Bar.
sp.l: Good faith, I think ye play me foul an ace,

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: No wife, she plays ye true.

sp.speaker: M●s. Bar.
sp.l: Peace husband, peace, I'll not be judged by you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Husband master Barnes, pray both go walk.
We cannot play, if standers by do talk.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Well to your game, we will not trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Where stands your man now?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Doth he not stand right?

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: It stands between the points.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: And that's my spite.
But yet methinks the dice runs much uneven,
That I throw but dews ase and you eleven.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: And yet you see that I cast down the hill,

sp.speaker: Mr Ba.
sp.l: Ay, I beshrew ye, 'tis not with my will.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Do ye beshrew me?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: No, I beshrew the dice.
That turn you up more at once, then me at twice.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Well, you shall see them turn for you anon.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: But I care not for them when your game is done,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: My game, what game?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Your game, your game at tables.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Well mistress, well, I have red Aesop's sables,
And know your morals meaning well enough.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Lo you'll be angry, now here's good stuff,

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: How now woman, who hath won the game?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gou.
sp.l: Nobody yet.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Your wife's the fairest far't.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I in your eye.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: He holds you fairer for't than I.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: For what forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Good gamester, for your game.

sp.speaker: Master Bar.
sp.l: Well, try it out, 'tis all but in the hearing.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Nay if it come to bearing, she'll be best.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Why, you're as good a bearer as the rest.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Nay that's not so, you bear one man too many.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Better do so then bear not any.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Beshrew me, but my wife's jests grow too bitter,
Plainer speeches for her were more better,
Malice lies emboweled in her tongue,
And new hatched hate makes every jest a wrong.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Look ye mistress now I hit ye.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Why I, you never use to miss a blot,
Especially when it stands so fair to hit.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: How mean ye mistress Barnes?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: That mistress gourse's in the hitting vain.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: I hot your man.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Ay, ay, my man, my man, but had I known,
I would have had my man stood nearer home.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Why had ye kept your man in his right place,
I should not then have hit him with an ace.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Right by the lord, a plague upon the bones.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: And a hot mischief on the curser too.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How now wife?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Why what's the matter woman?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: It is no matter. I am.

sp.speaker: M●s. Bar.
sp.l: I you are.

sp.speaker: M●s. Gou.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Why that's as you will be ever.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: That's every day as good as Barnes's wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: And better too, then what needs all this trouble?
A single horse is worse than that bears double.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wife go to, have regard to that you say,
Let not your words pass forth the verge of reason:
But keep within the bounds of modesty,
For ill report doth like a bailiff stand,
To pound the straying, and the wit-lost tongue,
And makes it forfeit into follies hands,
Well wife, you know 'tis no honest part,
To entertain such guests with jests and wrongs,
What will the neighbouring country vulgar say,
Whenas they hear that you fell out at dinner?
Forsooth they'll call it a pot quarrel straight,
The best they'll name it, is a woman's jangling,
Go too, be ruled, be ruled.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba●
sp.l: God's lord, be ruled, be ruled
What, think ye I have such a baby's wit,
To have a rod's correction for my tongue?
School infancy, I am of age to speak,
And I know when to speak, shall I be child for such a?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: What a? nay mistress speak it out,
I scorn your stopped compares, compare not me
To any but your equals, mistress Barnes,

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Peace wife be quiet.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O persuade, persuade.
Wife, mistress Goursey, shall I win your thoughts,
To composition of some kind effects?
Wife, if you love your credit leave this strife,
And come shake hands, with mistress Goursey here,

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Shall I shake hands? let her go shake her heels,
She gets nor hands, nor friendship at my hands,
And so sir while I live I will take heed,
What guests I bid again unto my house.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Impatient woman, will you be so stiff in this absurdness?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: I am impatient now I speak,
But sir I'll tell you more another time,
Go too, I will not take it as I have done.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Nay, she might stay, I will not long be here
To trouble her: well master Barnes,
I am sorry that it was our haps today,
To have our pleasures parted with this fray,
I am sorry too for all that is amiss,
Especially that you are moved in this,
But be not so, 'tis but a woman's jar,
Their tongues are weapons, words their blows of war,
Was but a while we buffeted you saw,
And each of us was willing to withdraw,
There was no harm nor bloodshed you did see:
Tush, fear us not, for we shall well agree:
I take my leave sir, come kind hearted man,
That speaks his wife so fair, I now and than,
I know you would not for an hundreth pound,
That I should hear your voices churlish sound,
I know you have a far more milder tune
Than peace, be quiet wife, but I have done:
Will ye go home? the door directs the way,
But if you will not, my duty is to stay.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, why here's a right woman, is there not?
They both have dined, yet see what stomachs they have.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Well master Barnes, we cannot do with all,
Let us be friends still.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O master Goursey, the mettle of our minds,
Having the temper of true reason in them,
Affords a better edge of argument,
For the maintain of our familiar loves,
Than the soft leaden wit of women can,
Wherefore with all the parts of neighbour love,
I impart myself to master Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And with exchange of love I do receive it,
Then here we'll part partners of two cursed wives.

sp.speaker: M. Ba
sp.l: O where shall we find a man so blessed that is not,
But come, your business and my home affairs,
Makes me deliver that unfriendly word amongst friends, farewell.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Twenty farewells sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: But hark ye master Goursey,
Look ye persuade at home as I will do,
What man, we must not always have them soes.

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: If I can help it.

sp.speaker: Master Bar.
sp.l: God help, God help,
Women are even untoward creatures still.

div.stage: Enter Philip, Francis and his boy from bowling.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come on Frank Goursey, you have good luck to win the game.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why tell me, is't not good, that never played before upon your green.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis good, but that it cost me ten good crowns that makes it worse.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let it not grieve thee man, come o'er to us,
We will devise some game to make you win
Your money back again sweet Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And that shall be ere long and if I live, but tell me Francis, what good horses have ye to hunt this summer?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Two or three jades, or so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be they but jades?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No faith my wag string here
Did founder one the last time that he rid,
The best grey nag that ever I laid my leg over.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You mean the flea bitten.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good sir the same.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And was the same the best that ere you rid on?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I was it sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'faith it was not sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, where had I one so good?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: One of my colour, and a better too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: One of your colour, I ne'er remember him, one of that colour.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Or of that complexion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What's that ye call complexion in a horse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The colour sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Set me a colour on your jest, or I will:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Nay good sir hold your hands.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, shall we have it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir, I cannot paint.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well then, I can. and I shall find a pencil for ye sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then I must find the table if you do.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A whoreson barren wicked urchin.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Look how you chafe, you would be angry more, if I should tell it you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Go to, I'll anger ye and if you do not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why sir, the horse that I do mean,
Hath a leg both straight and clean.
That hath nor spavine, splint nor flaw.
But is the best that ever ye saw,
A pretty rising knee, oh knee!
It is as round as round may be,
The full flank makes the buttock round,
This palfrey standeth on no ground,
Whenas my master's on her back,
If that he once do say but, tick,
And if he prick her, you shall see
Her gallop amain, she is so free,
And if he give her but a nod,
She thinks it is a riding rod:
And if he'll have her softly go,
Than she trips it like a doe,
She comes so easy with the rain,
A twine thread turns her back again,
And truly I did ne'er see yet;
A horse play proudlier on the bit,
My master with good managing,
Brought her first unto the ring,
He likewise taught her to curvet,
To run and suddenly to set,
she's cunning in the wild goose race,
Nay she's apt to every pace,
And to prove her colour good,
A flea enamoured of her blood,
Digged for channels in her neck,
And there made many a crimson speck,
I think there's none that use to ride,
But can her pleasant trot abide,
She goes so even upon the way,
She will not stumble in a day,
And when my master.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What do I?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O fie Frank fie,
Nay, nay, your reason hath no justice now,
I must needs say, persuade him first to speak,
Then chide him for it: tell me pretty wag,
Where stands his prancer, in what inn or stable?
Or hath thy master put her out to run,
Then in what field, what champion feeds this courser?
This well past bonny steed that thou so praisest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Faith sir I think.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Villain, what do ye think?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I think that you sir have been asked by many,
But yet I never heard that ye told any,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well boy, than I will add one more to many,
And ask thy master where this jennet feeds:
Come Frank tell me, nay prithee tell me Frank,
My good horse-master tell me, by this light
I will not steal her from thee: if I do,
Let me beheld a felon to thy love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No Philip no.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What, wilt thou were a point but with one tag?
Well Francis well, I see you are a wag.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: 'Swounds where he these timber turners, these troll the bowls, these green men, these.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What, what sir?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.p: These bowlers sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Well sir, what say you to bowlers?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Why I say they cannot be saved.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Your reason sir?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Because they throw away their souls at every mark

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Their souls, how mean ye?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Sirrah he means the soul of our bowl.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Lord how his wit holds bias like a bowl.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Well, which is the bias?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: This next to you.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Nay turn it this way, than the bowl goes true.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Rub, rub.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Why rub?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why you overcast the mark and miss the way.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Nay boy juse to take the fairest of my play.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Dick Coomes methinks thou art very pleasant. When got'st thou this merry humour?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: In your father's seller, the merriest place in th'house.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Then you have been carousing hard,

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Yes faith, 'tis our custom when your father's men and we mere.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thou art very welcome thither Dick.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: By God I thank ye sir, I thank ye sir, by God I have a quart of wine for ye sir in any place of the world, there shall not a servingman in Berkshire fight better for ye than I will do, if you have any quarrel in hand, you shall have the maidenhead of my new sword: I paid a quarter's wages for't by Jesus.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O this meat failer Dick,
How well t'as made apparel of his wit,
And brought it into fashion of an honour,
Prithee Dick Coomes but tell me how thou dost?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Faith sir like a poor man at service.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Or serving man.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Indeed so called by the vulgar.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why where the devil hadst thou that word?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: O sir, you have the most eloquenst ale in all the world, our blunt soil affords none such,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Philip leave talking with this drunken fool, say sirrah where's my father?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p:
Marry I thank ye for my ve●● good cheer, oh lord
it is not so much worth, you see I am bold with ye, indeed you are not so bold as welcome, I pray ye come oftener, truly I shall trouble ye, all these ceremonies are dispatched between them, and they are gone.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Are they so?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: I before God are they.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And wherefore came not you to call me then?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Because I was loath to change my game,

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: What game?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: You were at one sort of bowls, as I was at another,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sirrah, he means the buttery bowls of beer.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: By God sirrah we tickled it.

sp.speaker: Fra,
sp.l: Why what a swearing keeps this drunken ass,
Canst thou not say but swear at every word?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Peace do not mar his humour prithee Frank.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Let him alone, he's a springal, he knows not what belongs to an oath.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrah, be quiet, or I do protest.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Come, come, what do you protest?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By heaven to crack your crown,

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: To crack my crown, I lay yea crown of that,
Lay it down and ye dare:
Nay 'sblood, I'll venture a quarter's wages of that,
Crack my crown quoth 'a?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Will ye not be quiet, will ye urge me?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Urge ye with a pox, who urges ye?
You might have said so much to a clown,
Oh or one that had not been o'er the sea to see fashions,
I have I tell ye true, and I know what belongs to a man,
Crack my crown and ye can.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And I can ye rascal. Phi. Hold hair brain hold,
Dost thou not see he's drunk?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Nay let him come,
Though he be my master's son, I am my master's man,
And a man is a man in any ground in England:
Come, and he dare, 'a comes upon his death,
I will not budge an inch: no 'sblood will not,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye not?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Stay prithee Frank, Coomes dost thou hear?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Hear me no hears
Stand away, I'll trust none of you all,
If I have my back against a cart wheel,
I would not care, if the devil came.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why ye fool, I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Fool on your face, I have a wife,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She's a whore then.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: She's as honest as Nan Lawson.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What's she?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: One of his whores.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why hath he so many?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: I as many as there be churches in London.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that's an hundred and nine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Faith he lies a hundred.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then thou art a witness to nine.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.l: No by God, I'll be witness to none:

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Now do I stand like the George at Colbrooke:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No thou standst like the bull at s. Alban's.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Boy ye lie the horns.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The bull's bitten, see how he butts.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Comes, comes, put up, my friend and thou art friends

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: I'll hear him say so first.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Frank prithee do, be friends and tell him so,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to I am.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Put up sir, and ye be a man put up.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: I am easily persuaded boy.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Ah ye mad slave.

sp.speaker: Coomes
sp.l: Come, come, a couple of whoremasters I found
Ye, and so I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lo Frank dost thou not see he's drunk,
That twits me with my disposition?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What disposition?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nan Lawson, Nan Lawson,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay then,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go to ye wag, 'tis well,
If ever ye get a wife, i'faith I'll tell,
Sirrah at home we have a servingman,
He's not humoured bluntly as Coomes is,
yet his condition makes me often merry,
I'll tell thee sirrah, he's a fine neat fellow,
A spruce slave, I warrant ye, he'll have
His cruel garters cross about the knee,
His woollen hose, as white as the driven snow,
His shoes dry leather neat, and tied with red ribbons,
A nosegay bound with laces in his hat,
Bride-laces sir his hat, and all green hat.
Greene coverlet, for such a grass green wit,
The goose that grazeth on the green quoth he,
May I eat on, when you shall buried be,
All proverbs in his speech, he's proverbs all.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why speaks he proverbs?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Because he would speak truth,
And proverbs you'll confess, are old said sooth.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I like this well, and one day I'll see him,
But shall we part?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not yet, I'll bring you somewhat on your way,
And as we go, between your boy and you,
I'll know where that prancer stands at livery.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come, come you shall not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

div.stage: Enter master Barnes and his wife.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wife in my mind, today you were too blame
Although my patience did not blame ye for it:
Methought the rules of love and neighbourhood,
Did not direct your thoughts, all indirect
Were your proceedings, in the entertain
Of them that I invited to my house.
Nay stay. I do not chide but counsel wife,
And in the mildest manner that I may,
You need not view me with a servant's eye,
Whose vassals senses tremble at the look
Of his displeased master, oh my wife,
You are myself, when self sees fault in self.
Self is sin obstinate, if self amend not,
Indeed I saw a fault in thee myself,
and it hath set a foil upon thy fame,
Not as the foil doth grace the diamond.

sp.speaker: Mr Ba.
sp.l: What fault sir did you see in me today?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O do not set the organ of thy voice,
On such a grunting key of discontent:
Do not deform the beauty of thy tongue,
With such mishapen answers, rough wrathful words
Are bastards got by rashness in the thoughts,
Fair demeanours, are virtues nuptial babes,
The offspring of the well instructed soul,
Oh let them call thee mother, than my wife,
So seem not barren of good courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: So, have ye done?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Ay, and I had done well.
If you would do, what I advise for well.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Which is, that you would be good friends with mistress Goursey.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: With mistress Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Not so sweet husband.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Could you but show me any grounded cause.

sp.speaker: M. s. Bar.
sp.l: The grounded cause, I ground because I will not

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Your will hath little reason than I think.

sp.speaker: Master i Bar.
sp.l: Yes sir, my reason equalleth my will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Let's hear your reason, for your will is great.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Why for I will not.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Is all your reason, for I will not wife.
Now by my soul I held ye for more wise,
Discreet, and of more temperature in sense,
Then in a sullen humour to effect,
That woman's will born common scholar phrase,
Oft have I heard a timely married girl,
That newly left to call her mother mam,
Her father dad, but yesterday come from,
That's my good girl, God send thee a good husband,
And now being taught to speak the name of husband,
Will when she would be wanton in her will,
if her husband ask her why, say for I will,
Have I chid men for unmanly choice,
That would not sit their years, have I seen thee
Pupell such green young things, and with thy counsel,
Tutor their wits, a● dart thou now infected,
With this disease of imperfection,
I blush for thee ashamed at thy shame.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: A shame on her, that makes thee rate me so,

sp.speaker: M. Bar
sp.l: Oh black mouthed rage, thy breath is boisterous ▪
And thou mak'st virtue shake at this high storm,
She's of good report, I know thou knowest it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: She is not, nor I know not, but I know
That thou dost love her, therefore thinkst her so,
Thou bearest with her, because she bears with them ▪
Thou mayst be ashamed to stand in her defence,
She is a strumpet, and thou art no honest man
To stand in her defence against thy wife,
If I catch her in my walk now by cocks bones,
I'll scratch out both her eyes.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Nay never say oh God for the matter,
Thou art the cause, thou badst her to my house,
Only to blear the eyes of Goursey, didst not?
But I will ▪ send him word I warrant thee,
And ere I sleep to, trust upon it sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Methinks this is a mighty fault in her,
I could be angry with her: oh if I be so,
I shall but put a link unto a torch,
And so give greater light to see her fault:
I'll rather smother it in melancholy,
Nay, wisdom bids me shun that passion,
Than I will study for a remedy,
I have a daughter now heaven invocate,
She be not of like spirit as her mother,
〈◊〉 she'll be a plague unto her husband,
If that he be not patient and discreet,
For that I hold the ease of all such trouble,
Well, well, I would my daughter had a husband,
for I would see how she could demean herself,
In that estate, it may be ill enough,
And so God shall help me, well remembered now,
Frank Goursey is his father's some and heir,
A youth that in my heart I have good hope on,
My senses say a match, my soul applauds
The motion: oh but his lands are great,
He will look high why I will strain myself.
To make her dowry equal with his land,
Good faith and 'twere a match 'twould be a means,
To make their mother's friends: I'll call my daughter,
To see how shees disposed to marriage:
Mall, where are ye?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Father, here I am

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Where is your mother?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I saw her not forsooth, since you and she
Went walking both together to the garden.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Dost thou hear me girl? I must dispute with thee

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Father the question then must not be harded,
For I am very weak in argument.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well, this it is, I say 'tis good to marry.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And this say I, 'tis not good to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Were it not good, than all men would not marry
But now they do.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Marry not all, but it is good to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: It is both good and bad, how can this be?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why it is good to them that marry well,
To them that marry ill, no greater hell.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: If thou mightst marry well, wouldst thou agree?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I cannot tell, heaven must appoint for me.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wench I am studying forty good indeed,

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: My hopes and duty, wish your thoughts good speed

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: But tell me wench, hast thou a mind to marry:

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: This question is too hard for bashfulness,
And father, now ye pose my modesty,
I am a maid, and when ye ask me thus,
I like a maid must blush look pale and wan,
And then look pale again, for we change colour,
as our thoughts change, with true faced passion,
Of modest maidenhead, I could adorn me,
And to your question, make a sober curtsy,
And with close clipped civility be silent,
Or else say no forsooth, or I forsooth,
If I said no forsooth, I lied forsooth,
To lie upon myself were deadly sin,
Therefore I will speak truth and shame the devil,
Father, when first I heard you name a husband,
At that same very name, my spirits quickened,
Dispair before had killed them, they were dead,
Because it was my hap so long to tarry,
I was persuaded I should never marry.
And sitting sowing thus upon the ground,
I fell in trance of meditation,
But coming to myself, oh lord said I,
Shall it be so, must I unmarried die?
And being angry father, farther said,
Now by saint Anne, I will not die a maid,
Good faith before I came to this ripe groat,
I did accuse the labouring time of sloth,
Methought the year did run but slow about,
For I thought each year ten I was without,
Being fourteen, and towards the other year:
Good lord thought I, fifteen will ne'er be here,
For I have heard my mother say, that then
Pretty maids, were fit for handsome men,
Fifteen past, sixteen and seventeen too,
What, thought I, will not this husband do?
Will no man marry me, have men forsworn,
Such beauty and such youth? shall youth be worn
As rich men's gowns, more with age then use?
Why then I' let restrained fancy loose,
And bade it gaze for pleasure: then love swore me
To do whate'er my mother did before me,
Yet in good faith, I was very loath,
But now it lies in you to save my oath:
If I shall have a husband, get him quickly,
for maids that wears cork shoes, may step awry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Believe me wench, I do not apprehend thee,
But for this pleasant answer do commend thee.
I must confess, love doth thee mighty wrong,
But I will see thee have thy right ere long,
I know a young man, whom I hold most fit,
To have thee, both for living and for wit,
I will go write about it presently.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Good father do, oh god methinks I should
Wife it as fine as any woman could:
I could carry a port to he obeyed,
Carry a maistering eye upon my maid,
With minion do your business or I'll make ye,
And to all house authority be take me.
O God would I were married, be my troth,
But if I be not, I swear I'll keep my oath.

sp.speaker: Enter mistress Ba.
sp.l: How now minion, where have you been gadding

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Forsooth my father called me forth to him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Your father, and what said he too ye I pray?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nothing forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Nothing that cannot be, something he said.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I something, that as good as nothing was.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Come let me hear, that something nothing then

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nothing but of a husband for me mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: A husband, that was something, but what husband

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nay faith I know not mother, would I did.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I would ye did, i'faith are ye so hasty?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Hasty mother, why how old am I?

sp.speaker: Master Ba.
sp.l: Too young to marry.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay by the mass ye lie
Mother, how old were you when you did marry.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: How old soe'er I was, yet you shall tarry.

sp.speaker: M●ll.
sp.l: Then the worse for me, hark mother hark,
The priest forgets that ere he was a clerk,
When you were at my years, I'll hold my life,
Your mind was to change maidenhead for wife,
Pardon me mother, I am of your mind,
And by my troth I take it but by kind.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Do ye hear daughter, you shall stay my leisure

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Do you hear mother, would you stay from pleasure
When ye have mind to it? go to, there's no wrong
Like this, to let maids lie alone so long
Lying alone they muse but in their beds,
How they might lose their long kept maiden heads,
This is the cause there is so many scapes,
For women that are wise, will not lead apes
In hell, I tell ye mother I say true,
Therefore come husband, maiden head adieu.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Well lusty guts, I mean to make ye stay,
And set some rubs in your minds smothest way.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: How now sirrah, where have ye been walking?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Over the meads half way to Milton mother,
To bear my friend Frank Goursey company.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Where's your blue coat, your sword and buckler sir
Get you such like habit for a servingman,
If you will weight upon the brat of Goursey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother, that you are moved this makes me wonder,
When I departed I did leave ye friends,
What undigested jar hath since betided?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Such as almost doth choke thy mother boy.
And stifles her with the conceit of it,
I am abused my son by Goursey's wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By mistress Goursey?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Mistress flirt, you foul strumpet,
Light alone, short heels, mistress Goursey,
Call her again and thou were better no.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O my dear more have some patience,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Ay sir, have patience, and see your father
To rifle up the treasure of my love,
And play the spendthrift upon such an harlot?
This same will make me have patience, will it not?

sp.speaker: Phil●.
sp.l: This same is women's most impatience,
Yet mother I have often heard ye say,
That you have found my father temperate,
And ever free from such affections.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Ay, till my too much love did glut his thoughts,
and make him seek for change,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O change your mind
My father bears more cordial love to you.

sp.speaker: Mistress B.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou liest, for he loves Goursey's wife, not me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now I swear mother you are much too blame,
I durst be sworn he loves you as his soul.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Wilt thou be pampered by affection?
Will nature teach thee such vild perjury?
Wilt thou be sworn, I forlorn, careless boy?
And if thou swearest, I say he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He loves ye but too well I swear,
Unless ye knew much better how to use him,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Doth he so sir? thou unnatural boy,
Too well sayest thou, that word shall cost thee somewhat,
O monstrous, have I brought thee up to this?
Too well, oh unkind, wicked and degenerate,
Hast thou the heart to say so of thy mother?
Well, God will plague thee sort, I warrant thee,
Out on thee villain, fie upon thee wretch,
Out of my sight, out of my sight I say.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This air is pleasant, and doth please me well,
And here I will stay,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Wilt thou stubborn villain?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Thou setst thy son to scoff and mock at me,
Is't not sufficient I am wronged of thee?
But he must be an agent to abuse me?
Must I be subject to my cradle too? O God, oh God amend it.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why how now Philip, is this true my son?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear father she is much impatient:
Ne'er let that hand assist me in my need,
If I more said, then that she thought amiss,
To think that you were so licentious given,
And thus much more, when she inferred it more,
I swore an oath you loved her but too well,
In that as guilty I do hold myself,
Now that I come to more considerate trial,
I know my fault, I should have born with her,
Blame me for rashness, than not for want of duty.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: I do absolve thee, and come hither Philip,
I have writ a letter unto master Goursey,
And I will tell thee the contents thereof,
But tell me first, thinkst thou Frank Goursey? loves thee?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: If that a man devoted to a man,
Loyal, religious, in love's hallowed vows,
If that a man that is soul laboursome,
To work his own thoughts to his friend's delight,
May purchase good opinion with his friend,
Than I may say ▪ I have done this so well,
That I may think Frank Goursey loves me well.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and I am much deceived in him,
And if he be not sober, wise, and valiant.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I hope my father takes me for thus wise,
I will not glue myself in love to one,
That hath not some desert of virtue in him,
Whate'er you think of him, believe me father,
He will be answerable to your thoughts,
In any quality commendable.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Thou cheer'st my hopes in him, and in good faith,
Thou'st made my love complete unto thy friend,
Philip I love him, and I love him so,
I could afford him a good wife I know.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Father, a wife?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Philip a wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I lay my life my sister.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I in good faith.

sp.speaker: Ph●.
sp.l: Then father he shall have her he shall I swear.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How canst thou say so knowing not his mind?

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: All is one for that, I will go to him straight,
Father if you would seek this seven years day,
You could not find a fitter match for her,
And he shall have her, I swear he shall,
He were as good be hanged as once deny her, I saith I'll to him

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Hairebraine, Hairebraine ▪ stay,
As yet we do not know his father's mind,
Why what will master Goursey say my son,
If we should ●otion it without his knowledge?
Go to, he's a wise and discreet gentleman,
And that respects from me all honest parts,
nor shall he fail his expectation,
First I do mean to make him privy to it,
Philip this letter is to that effect.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father, for god's sake send it quickly then,
I'll call your man, what Hugh, where's Hugh, there h●.

sp.speaker: Master Bar.
sp.p: Philip if this would prove a match, it were the only means that could be found, to make thy mother friends with mist. Gou. Phil how a match? I'll warrant ye a match
sp.l: My sister's fair, Frank goursie he is rich,
His dowry too, will be sufficient,
Franke's young, and youth is apt to love,
And by my troth my sister's maiden head
Stands like a game at tennis, if the ball
Hit into the hole or hazard, farewell all.

sp.speaker: Ma. Bar.
sp.l: How now, where's Hugh?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why what doth this proverbial with us, why where's Hugh?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where's Hugh I say?

sp.speaker: Master Bar.
sp.l: Be not so hasty Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father let me alone,
I do it but to make myself some sport,
This formal fool your man speaks naught but proverbs,
And speak men what they can to him, he'll answer
With some time, rotten sentence, or old saying,
Such spokes as the ancient of the parish use,
With neighbour 'tis an old proverb and a true,
Goose giblets are good meat, old sack better than new,
Then says another, neighbour that is true,
And when each man hath drunk his gallon round,
A penny pot, for that's the old man's gallon,
Then doth he lick his lips and stroke his beard,
That's glued together with his slavering drops,
Of yeasty ale, and when he scarce can trim,
His gouty fingers, thus he'll fillip it,
And with a rotten hem say heigh my hearts,
Merry go so●●y cock and pie my hearts,
But then their saving penny proverb comes,
And that is this: they that will to the wine,
By’r lady mistress shall lay their penny to mine,
This was one of this penny-fathers bastards,
for on my life he was never begotten,
Without the consent of some great proverb-monger.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O ye are a wag.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, now unto my business;
'Swounds will that mouth that's made of old said saws,
And nothing else, say nothing to us now?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O 〈…〉 you must not leap over the style before you come at it, haste makes waste, soft fire makes sweet mast, not too fast for falling, there's no haste to hang true men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Father we have't, ye see we have't, now will I see if my memory will serve for some proverbs too. O a painted cloth were as well worth a trifling, as a these worth a halten well, after my hearty commendations, as I was at the making hereof ▪ so it is, that I hope as you speed, so you're sure a swift horse will tire, but he that trots easily will endure, you have most learnedly proverbed it, commending the virtue of patience or forbearance, but yet you know forbearance is no quittance.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I promise ye master Philip you have spoken as true as steel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Father, there's a proverb well applied.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And it seemeth unto me, I it seems to me, that you master Philip mock me, do you not know qui mocat mo●●bitur, mock age and see how it will prosper?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why ye whoreson proverb book bound up in folio,
Have ye no other sense to answer me,
But every word a proverb, no other English?
Well, I'll fulfil a proverb on thee straight.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: What is it sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'd fetch my fist from thine ear,

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Bear witness he threatens me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father that same is the cowards common proverb:,
But come, come sirrah, tell me where Hugh is?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I may and I will, I need not except I list, you shall not command me, you glue me neither meat, drink, nor wages, I am your father's man, and a man's a man, and 'a have but a hose on his head, do not misuse me so, do not, for though he that is bound must obey, yet he that will not tarry, may run away so he may.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Peace Nick, I'll see he shall use thee well,
Go to peace sirrah, here Nick take this let ,
carry it to him to whom it is directed.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: To whom is it?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why read it, canst thou read?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Forsooth though none of the best yet meanly:

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why dost thou not use it?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Forsooth as use makes perfectness, so seldom seen is soon forgotten.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.p: Well said, but go, it is to master Goursey,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now sir, what proverb have ye to deliver a letter?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What need you to care? who speaks to you? you may speak when you are spoken to, and keep your wind to cool your pottage: well, well, you are my master's son and you look for his land, but they that hope for dead men's shoes, may hap to go barefoot: take heed, as soon goes the young sheep to the pot as the old. I pray God save my master's life, for seldom comes the better.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O he hath given it me: farewell proverbs.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Farewell frost,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shall I fling an old shoe after ye?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: No, you should say God send fair weather after me,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I mean for good luck.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: A good luck on ye.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Alas poor fool, he uses all his wit,
Philip in faith this mirth hath cheered thought,
And cozened it of his right play of passion,
Go after nick, and when thou thinkst he's there,
Go in and urge to that which I have writ,
I'll in these meadows make a cerckling walk,
And in my meditation conjure so,
As that some send of thought self-eating anger,
Shall by my spells of treason vanish quite
Away, and let me beat from thee tonight .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tonight , yes that you shall, but hark ye father,
Look that you my sister waking keep,
For Frank I swear shall kiss her ere I sleep.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I am very dry with walking o'er the green,
Butler some beer, sirrah call the butler.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay faith sir, we must have some smith to give the butler
a drench, or cut him in the forehead, for he hath got
A horse's disease, namely the staggers, tonight he's a good
Housewife, he reels all that he wrought today, and he were good
Now to play at dice, for he casts excellent well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How meanst thou, is he drunk?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but I am sure he hath more liquor in him
Then a whole dicker of hides, he's socked thoroughly i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well go and call him, bid him bring me drink.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother powers and will look merrily,
Neither upon my father nor on me,
He says she fell out with mistress barns today,
Than I am sure they'll no: be quickly friends,
Good lord what kind of creatures women are?
Their love is lightly won and lightly lost,
And then their hate is deadly and extreme.
He that doth take a wife, betakes himself
To all the cares and troubles of the world,
Now her disquietness doth grieve my father,
Grieves me, and troubles all the house besides,
What, shall I have so ne drink? how now a horn?
Belike the drunken slave is fallen asleep ,
And now the boy doth wake him with his horn,
How now sirrah, where's the butler?

sp.speaker: Enter boy.
sp.p: Marry sir, where he was even now asleep , but I waked him, and when he waked, he thought he was in master Barnses buttery, for he stretched himself thus: and yawning said, Nick, honest Nick fill a fresh bowl of ale, stand to it nick and thou beest a man of god's making, stand to it, and then I winded my horn, and he's horn mad.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Boy heigh, ho boy, and thou beest a man draw, oh here's a blessed moonshine God be thanked, boy is not this goodly weather for barley?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Spoken like a right maulster Hodge, but dost thou hear? Thou art not drunk.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: No, I scorn that i'faith.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But thy fellow Dick Coomes is mightily drunk.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Drunk, a plague on it, when a man cannot carry his drink well: 'sblood I'll stand to it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Hold man, see and thou canst stand first,

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Drunk? he's a beast and he be drunk, there's no man that is a sober man will be drunk, he's a boy and he be drunk.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, he's a man as thou art.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Thus 'tis when a man will not be ruled by his friends, I bade him keep under the lee, but he kept down the weather two bows, I told him he would be taken with a planet, but the wisest of us all may fall.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: True Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Whope lend me thy hand Dick, I am fallen into a well, lend me thy hand, I shall be drowned else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hold fast by the bucket

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Hodge, a rope on it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I there is a rope on it, but where art thou Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: In a well, I prithee draw up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come give up thy body, wind up, hoist.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.l: I am over head and ears,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: In all Hodge, in all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How loathsome is this beast man's shape to me?
This mould of reason so unreasonable,
Sirrah, why dost thou trip him down seeing he's drunk?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Because sir I would have drunkards cheap.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How mean ye?

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: Why they say, that when any thing hath a fall, it is cheap, and so of drunkards.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Go to help him up, but hark who knocks?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Sir, here's one of master Barnsy's men with a letter to my old master. Fran. Which of them is it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They call him Nicholas sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go call him in.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: By your leave ho, how now young master how is't?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Look ye sirrah, where your fellow lies,
He's in a fine taking, is he not?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Whope Hodge, were art thou man, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: O in a well.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: In a well man, nay then thou art deep in understanding,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I once today you were almost so sir,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Who I, go to young master, I do not like this humour
in ye 〈…〉 give every man his doe, and give him no more: say I was in such a case, go to 'tis the greatest indignation that can be offered to a man: and but a man's more god her given, you were able to make him swear out his hear: blood, what though-that 〈…〉 he ere or as some say, cut a feather: what though he be 〈◊〉 misled, band, or as it were 'tis no consequent to me: you know i have drunk all the alehouses in Abington dry, and laidthe taps on the tables when i had done: 'sblood I'll challenge all the true rob. pots 〈…〉, to leap up to the chin in a barrel of beer, and if i can not drink it down to my foot ere i leave, and then set the tap in the midst of the house, and then turn a good turn on the toe on it, let me be counted nobody , a●pingler, nay let me be bound to drink nothing but small beer seven years after, and I had as 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Peace sir, I must speak with one, Nicholas I think your name is,

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: True as the skin between your brows.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, how doth my master?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Forsooth live, and the best doth no better.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where is the letter he hath sent me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis right as Philip said, 'tis a fine fool,
This letter is directed to my father.
I'll carry it to him, Dick Coomes make him drink.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Ay, I'll make him drunk and he will.

sp.speaker: Nicho
sp.l: Not so Richard, it is good to be 〈…〉

sp.p: Well Nicholas, as thou art Nicholas, welcome, but as thou art Nicholas and a boon companion, ten times welcome, Nicholas give me thy hand; shall we be 〈◊〉? and we shall, say but we shall, and let the first word stand.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Indeed as long lives the merry man 〈…〉,
A ounce of debt will not pay a pound of care?

sp.speaker: Coom,
sp.l: Nay, a pound of care will not pay a ounce of debt.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Well, 'tis a good horse never stumbles but who lies here?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: 'Tis our Hodge, and I think he lies asleep , you made him drunk at your house to but I'll pepper some of you fort.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I Richard, I know you'll put a man over the shoes, and if you can, but he's a fool will take more than will do him good.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: 'Sblood ye shall take more than will do ye good,
Or I'll make ye clap under the table.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Nay, I hope, as I have temperance to forbear drink so have I patience to endure 〈…〉 company doth, for when a man doth to Rome come, he must do as there is done,

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p: Ha my resolve nick Frolagogene, fill the pot hostess, swoons you whore, harry Hooke's a rascal: help me but carry my fellow Hodge in, and we'll crush it I i'faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By this I think, the letter is delivered,
And 'twill be shortly time that I step in,
And woo their favours for my sister's fortune,
And yet I need not, she may do as well,
But yet not better, as the case doth stand,
Between our mothers it may make them friends,
Nay I would swear that she would do as well,
Were she a stranger to 〈…〉
But they are so acquainted, their ne'er part,
Why she will flout the devil and make blush
The boldest face of man, that ever man saw,
He that hath best opinion 〈…〉 wit,
And hath his brain pan fraught with bitter jests,
Or of his own, or stolen, or how 〈◊〉,
Let him: stand here so high in his own conceit,
Her wit's a sun, that melts him down like butter,
And makes him sit at table 〈◊〉 wise,
Flat, flat, 〈…〉 a word to say,
Yet she'll not love him then, but like a tyrant,
She'll persecute the poor wit-beaten man,
And so be bang him with dry bobs and scoffs,
When he is down, most cowardly good faith,
As I have pitied the poor patient.
There came a farmer's son a-wooing to her,
A proper man, well landed too he was,
A man that for his wit need not to ask,
What time a year 'twere good to sow his oats,
Nor yet his barley, no nor when to reap,
To plow his fallowes, or to fell his trees,
well experienced thus each kind of way,
After a two months labour at the most,
And yet 'twas well he held it out so long,
He left his love, she had so last his lips,
He could say nothing to her, but God be with ye,
Why she, when men have dined and call for cheese,
Will straight maintain jests bitter to digest,
And then some one will fall to argument,
Who if he over master her with reason,
Then she'll begin to buffet him with mocks,
Well I do doubt, Frances hath so much spleen,
They'll ne'er agree, but I will moderate.
By this time, 'tis time I think to enter,
This is the house, shall I knock? no I will not
Wait while one comes out to answer:
I'll in, and let them be as bold with us.

div.stage: Enter master Goursey reading a letter.

sp.speaker: M. Gour
sp.l: If that they like her dowry shall be equal,
To your son's wealth or possibility,
It is a means to make our wines good friends,
And to continue friendship twi● to two,
'Tis so indeed, I like this motion,
sp.p: And it hath my consent, because my wife, is sore infected and heart sick with hate: and I have sought the Galen of advice, which only tells me this same potion, to be most sovereign for her sickness cure.
sp.l: Here comes my son, conferring with his friend,
Frances, how do you like your friend's discourse?
I know he is persuading to this motion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Father, as matter that befits a friend,
But yet not me, that am too young to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.p: Nay, if thy mind be forward with thy years, the time is lost thou tarriest, trust me boy, this match is answerable to thy birth, her blood and portion give each other grace: these indented lines promise a sum, and I do like the value, if it hap thy liking to accord to my consent, it is a match: wilt thou go see the maid?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ne'er trust me father, the shape of marriage,
which I do see in others, seem so severe,
I dare not put my youngling liberty,
Under the awe of that instruction,
And yet I grant the limits of free youth
Going astray, are often restrained by that:
But mistress wedlock, to my scholar thoughts,
Will be too cursed I fear, oh should she snip,
My pleasure aiming mind, I shall be sad,
And swear, when I did marry I was mad.

sp.speaker: Master Gour.
sp.l: But boy, let my experience teach thee this,
Yet in good faith, thou speakst not much amiss,
When first thy mother's same to me did come,
Thy grandsire thus, then came to me his son,
And even my words to thee, to me he said,
And as to me thou sayest, to him I said,
But in a greater huff, and hotter blood,
I tell ye, on youth's tiptoes then I stood,
Says he (Good faith this was his very say)
When I was young, I was but reason's fool,
And went to wedding, as to wisdom's school:
It taught me much, and much I did forget,
But beaten much by it, I got some wit,
Though I was shackled from an often scout,
Yet I would wanton it when I was out,
'Twas comfort, old acquaintance then to meet,
Restrained liberty, attained is sweet,
Thus said my father to thy father, son
And thou mayst do this to, as I have done.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: In faith good counsel Frank, what sayest thou to it?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Philip, what should I say?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, either I or no.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O but which rather?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that which was persuaded by thy father.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That's I, than I, o should it fall out ill.
Then I, for I am guilty of that ill.
I'll not be guilty, no.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What backward gone?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Philip, no whit backward, that is on.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: On then,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O stay.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tush, there is no good luck in this delay,
Come, come, late comer's man are shent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Heigh ho, I fear I shall repent,
well, which way Frank?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why this way.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Canst thou tell?
And takest upon thee to be my guide to hell,
But which way father?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: That way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ay, you know,
You found the way to sorrow long ago,
Father God boy ye, you have sent your son,
To seek on earth an earthly day of doom,
Where I shall be judged, alack the ruth,
To penance for the follies of my youth.
Well I must go, but by my troth my mind,
Is not love capable to that kind,
Oh I have looked upon this mould of men,
As I have done upon a lion's den,
Praised I have the gallant beast I saw,
Yet wished me no acquaintance with his paw,
And must I now be grated with them, well,
Yet I may hap to prove a Daniel,
And if I do sure it would make me laugh,
To be among wild beasts and yet be safe,
Is there a remedy to abate their rage,
Yes many catch them, and put them in a cage,
I but how catch them, marry in your hand,
Carry me forth a burning firebrand,
For with his sparkling shine, old rumor says,
A firebrand the swiftest runner frays,
This I may do, but if it prove not so,
Then man goes out to seek his adjunct woe,
Philip away, and father now adieu,
In quest of sorrow I am sent by you.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Return the messenger of joy my son.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Seldom in this world, such a work is done.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay, nay, make haste, it will be quickly night.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why is it not good to woo by candle light.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But if we make not haste they'll be a-bed .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The better candles out, and curtains spread

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: I know, though that my sons years be not many.
Yet he hath wit to woo as well as any,
Here comes my wife, I am glad my boy is gone.
Ere she came hither, how now wife, how is't?
What are ye yet in charity and love with mistress barns?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou,
sp.l: What mistress barns, why mistress Barnes I pray

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Because she is your neighbour and

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: And what?
And a jealous slandering spiteful quean she is,
One that would blur my reputation,
With her approbrious malice if she could,
She wrongs her husband, to abuse my fame,
'Tis known that I have lived in honest name,
All my life time, and been your right true wife,

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: I entertain no other thought my wife,
And my opinion's sound of your behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.l: And my behaviour is as sound as it,
But her ill speeches seeks to rot my credit,
And eat it with the worm of hate and malice.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why then preserve it you by patience.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: By patience, would ye have me shame myself,
And cozen myself to bear her injuries:
Not while her eyes be open will I yield,
A word, a letter, a syllable's value,
But equal and make even her wrongs to me,
To her again.

sp.speaker: Master Gou.
sp.l: Then in good faith wife ye are more to blame.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Am I too blame sir pray what letters this.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: There is a dearth of manners in ye wife,
Rudely to snatch it from me, give it me?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: You shall not have it, till I have read it.

sp.speaker: Master Gou.
sp.l: Give me it then, and I will read it to you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou,
sp.l: No, no, it shall not need, I am a scholar
Good enough to read a letter sir,

sp.speaker: M. Gou
sp.l: God's passion, if she knew but the contents,
She'll seek to cross this match, she shall not read it.
Wife, give it me, come, come, give it me.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Husband, in very deed you shall not have it.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: What will you move me to impatience then?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Tut, tell not me of your impatience,
But since you talk sir of impatience,
You shall not have the letter by this light,
Till I have read it, soul I'll burn it first.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Go to, ye move me wife, give me the letter,
Introth I shall grow angry, if you do not.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Grow to the house top with your anger sir.
Ne'er tell me, I care not thus much for it.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Well, I can bear enough, but not too much,
Come give it me, 'twere best you be persuaded,
By God ye make me swear, now God forgive me,
Give me I say, and stand not long upon it,
Go to, I am angry at the heart, my very heart,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Heart me no hearts ▪ you shall not have it sir,
No you shall not, ne'er look so big,
I will nor be afraid at your great looks,
You shall not have it, no you shall not have it.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Shall I not have it, introth I'll try that,
Minion I'll ha't, shall I not ha't, I am loath,
Go too, take pausement, be advised,
In faith I will, and stand not long upon it,
A woman of your years, I am ashamed,
A couple of so long continuance,
Should thus, God's foot, I cry God heartily mercy,
Go to, ye vex me, and I'll vex ye for it,
Before I leave ye, I will make ye glad,
To tender it on your knees, hear ye, I will I will,
What worse and worse stomach, give ye faith,
Shall I be crossed by you in my old age?
And where I should have greatest comfort to,
A nurse of you nursed in the devil's name,
Go to mistress, by God's precious dear,
If ye delay.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Lord ▪ lord, why in what a fit,
Are you in husband, so enraged, so moved,
And for so slight a cause, to read a letter,
Did this letter love, contain my death,
Should you deny my sight of it, I would not,
Not see my sorrow, not eschew my danger,
But willingly yield me a patient,
Unto the doom that your displeasure gave:
Here is the letter, not for that your incensement,
Makes me make offer of it, but your health,
Which anger I do fear hath erased.
And viper like hath sucked away the blood,
That wont was to be cheerful in this cheek,
How pale ye look.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Pale, can ye blame me for it, I tell you true,
An easy matter could not thus have moved me,
Well this resignment, and so forth, but woman
This fortnight shall I not forget ye for it.
Ha, ha, I see that roughness can do somewhat,
I did not think good faith, I could have set,
So sour a face upon it, and to her,
My bed embracer, my right bosom friend,
I would not that she should have seen the letter
As poor a man as I am by my troth
For twenty pound: well I am glad I have it.
Ha, here's ado about a thing of nothing,
What stomach, ha, 'tis happy you're come down.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Well crafty fox, I'll hunt ye by my troth,
Deal ye so closely? well I see his drift.
He would not let me see the letter, lest
That I should cross the match, and I will cross it.

sp.speaker: Enter Comes.
sp.l: Dick Coomes?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Forsooth.

sp.speaker: M●s. Gour.
sp.l: Come hither Dick, thou art a man I love,
And one whom I have much in my regard,

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: I thank ye for it mistress, I thank ye for it,

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Nay here's my hand, I will do very much for thee
If e'er thou standst in need of me,
Thou shall not lack, whilst thou hast a day to live.
Money apparel.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: And sword and bucklers.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: And sword and bucklers too my gallant Dick,
So thou wilt use but this in my defence.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
This, no faith I have no mind to this, break my head if this break not if we come to any tough play, nay mistress I had a sword, I the flower of Smithfield for a sword a right fox i'faith, with that and a man had come over with a smooth and a sharp stroke, it would have cried twang, and then when I had doubled my point, traced my ground, and had carried my buckler before me like a garden ●ut, and then come in with a cross blow, and over the pick of his buckler two else long, it would have cried twang, twang, mettle, mettle: but a dog hath his day, 'tis gone, and there
are few good ones made now, I see by this dearth of good swords, that dearth of sword and buckler fight, begins to grow out, I am sorry for it, I shall never see good manhood again, if it be once gone, this poking fight of rapier and dagger will come up then ▪ then a man, a tall man, and a good sword and buckler man, will be spitted like a cat or a coney, than a boy will be as good as a man, unless the lord show mercy unto us, well, I had as heaven be hanged as live to see that day, well mistress, what shall I do? what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.l: Why this brave Dick,
Thou knowest that Goursey's wife and I am foes:
Now man me to her house,
And though it be dark Dick, yet we'll have no light,
Lest that thy master should prevent our journey
By seeing our depart: then when we come,
And if that she and I do fall to words,
Set in thy foot and quarrel with her men,
Draw, fight, strike, hurt, but do not kill the slaves,
And make as though thou struckst at a man,
And hit her and thou canst, a plague upon her,
She hath misused me Dick, wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Yes mistress I will strike her men, but God forbid,
That ere Dick Coomes should be seen to strike a woman.

sp.speaker: Mr Gour.
sp.l: Why she is mankind, therefore thou mayst strike her.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Mankind, nay and she have any part of a man, I'll strike her I warrant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gour.
sp.l: That's my good Dick, that's my sweet Dick,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: 'Swounds who would not be a man of valour to have such words of a gentlewoman, one of their words are more to me then twenty of these russet coats cheesecake; and buttermakers: well, I thank God I am none of these cowards, well and a man have any virtue in him, I see he shall be regarded.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.p: Art thou resolved Dick? wilt thou do this for me, and it thou wilt, here is an earnest penny, of that rich guerdon I do mean to give thee.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
An angel mistress let me see, stand you on my left hand, and let the angel lie on my buckler on my right hand, for fear of losing, now here stand I to be tempted,
they say, every man hath two spirits attending on him, either good or bad, now I say a man hath no other spirits but either his wealth or his wife, now which is the better of them, why that is as they are used, for use neither of them well, and they are both naught, but this is a miracle to me, that gold that is heavy hath the upper, and a woman that is light doth soonest fall, considering that light things aspire, and heavy things soonest go down, but leave these considerations to sir John, they become a black coat better than a blue, well mistress I had no mind to day to quarrel, but a woman is made to be a man's seducer, you say quarrel.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou. i
sp.p: Coom. There speaks an angel, is it good?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Then I cannot do amiss, the good angel goes with me.

div.stage: Enter sir Raph Smith his lady and Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Raph.
sp.l: Come on my hearts, i'faith it is ill luck,
To hunt all day and not kill any thing,
What sayest thou lady, art thou weary yet?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I must not say so sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ra.
sp.l: Although thou art.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And can you blame her to be forth so long,
And see no better sport?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good faith 'twas very hard.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No 'twas not ill.
Because you know it is not good to kill.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes venison lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No indeed nor them,
Life is as dear in dear as 'tis in men.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But they are killed for sport.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But that's bad play,
When they are made to sport their lives away.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: 'Tis fine to see the run.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What out of breath?
They run but ill that run themselves to death,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: They might make then less haste and keep their wind.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why then they see the hounds brings death behind.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Then 'twere as good for them at first to stay,
As to run long and run their lives away.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I but the stoutest of you all that's here,
Would run from death, and nimbly scud for fear,
Now by my troth I pity those poor elves.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Well, they have made us but bad sport today.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes 'twas my sport to see them scape away.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I wish that I had been at one bucks fall.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Out thou wood-tyrant thou art worst of all.

sp.speaker: Wil ..
sp.l: A woodman lady, but no tyrant I.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes tyrantlike thou lovest to see lives die.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Lady no more, I do not like this luck,
To hunt all day and yet not kill a buck,
Well, it is late, but yet I swear I will
Stay here all night, but I a buck will kill.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: All night, nay good sir Raph smith do not so.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Content ye lady, will, go fetch my bow,
A berry of fair roes I saw today,
Down by the groves, and there I'll take my stand,
And shoot at one, God send a lucky hand.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Will ye not then sir Raph go home with me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No, but my men shall bear thee company.
Sirs man her home, will bid the huntmen couple,
And bid them well reward their hounds tonight .
Lady farewell, will haste ye with the bow,
I'll stay for thee here by the grove below.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I will, but 'twill be dark I shall not see,
How shall I see ye then?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why hollo to me, and I will answer thee.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Enough, I will.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How willingly dost thou consent to go,
To fetch thy master that same killing bow.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Guilty of death I willing am in this,
Because 'twas our ill haps today to miss,
To hunt and not to kill is hunter's sorrow,
Come lady, we'll have venison ere tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come Frank now are we hard by the house,
But how now, sad?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, to study how to woe thy sister.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How man, how to woe her? why no matter how,
I am sure thou wilt not be ashamed to woe,
thy cheeks not subject to a childish blush,
Thou hast a better warrant by thy wit,
I know thy oratory can unfold,
Quick invention, plausible discourse,
And set such painted beauty on thy tongue,
As it shall ravish every maiden sense,
For Frank, thou art not like the russet youth
I told thee of, that went to woe a wench,
And being full stuffed up with fallow wit,
And meadow matter, asked the pretty maid,
How they sold corn last market day with them.
Saying: indeed 'twas very dear wit them:
And do ye hear, he had not need do so,
For she will Francis throughly try your wit,
Sirrah she'll bow the mettle of your wits,
And if they crack she will not hold ye currant,
Nay she will weigh your wits as men may angels,
And if I lack a grain, she will not chanke with ye,
I cannot speak it but in passion,
She is a wicked wench to make a jest,
Ay me how full of flouts and mocks she is?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Some aquavitae reason to recover,
This sick discourser, soond not prithee Philip,
Tush, tush, I do not think her as thou sayest,
Perhaps she's opinions darling Philip:
Wise in repute, the crow's bird oh my friend,
Some judgements slave themselves to small desert,
And wondernize the birth of common wit,
When their wone strangeness do but make that strange,
And their ill errors do but make that good,
And why should men debase to make that good,
Perhaps such admiration wins her wit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, I am glad to hear this bold prepare,
For this encounter, forward hardy Frank,
Yonder's the window, with the candle in't,
Belike she's putting on her night attire,
I told ye Frank 'twas late, well I will call her,
Marry softly that my mother may not hear:
Mall, sister Mall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How now, who's there?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis I,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis I, who I? I quoth the dog, or what?
A Christ cross rowel?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No sweet pinkany.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O is't you wild oats?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I forsooth wanton.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well said scapethrift.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Philip be these your usual best salutes?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This is the harmless chiding of that dove,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dove, one of those that draw the Queen of love?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How now? Who's that brother, who's that with ye?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A gentleman my friend.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Belady he hath a pure wit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How means your holy judgement?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O well put in sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Up you would say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well climbed gentleman,
I pray sir tell me, do you cart the Queen of love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not cart her, but couch her in your eye,
And a fit place for gentle love to lie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I but methinks you speak without the book,
