To place a sour wheel waggon in my look,
Where will you have room to have the coachman sit?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay, that were but small manners, and not fit,
His duty is before you bare to stand,
Having a lusty whipstock in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The place is void, will you provide me one?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And if you please I will supply the room.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But are ye cunning in the carman's lash?
And can ye whistle well?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes I can well direct the coach of love.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ah cruel carter, would you whip a dove?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark ye sister?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay, but hark ye brother?
Whose white boy is that same? know ye his mother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He is a gentleman of a good house.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why is his house of gold, is it not made of lime and stone like this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I mean he's well descended.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: God be thanked.
Did he descend some steeple or some ladder?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Well, you will still be cross, I tell ye sister,
This gentleman by all your friends consent,
Must be your husband.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay not all, some sing another note,
My mother will say no, I hold a groat.
But I thought 'twas somewhat, he would be a carter,
He hath been whipping lately some blind bear,
And now he would seek the blind boy here with us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, do you hear, you sister, mistress would have
You that do long for somewhat I know what.
My father told me, go too I'll tell all,
If ye be cross, do ye hear me? I have laboured
A years work in this afternoon for ye,
Come from your cloister, votary, chase nun,
Come down and kiss Frank Goursey's mother's son.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Kiss him I pray?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Go to, stale maidenhead ▪ come down I say,
You seventeen and upward, come come down,
You'll stay till twenty else for your wedding gown,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nun, votary, stale maidenhead, seventeen and upward,
Here be names, what nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes, or a fair built steeple without bells,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Steeple good people, nay another cast.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ay, or a well made ship without a mast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fie not so big sir, by one part of four.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why then ye are a boat without an oar,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O well rode wit, but what's your fare I pray?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your fair self must be my fairest pay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay, and you be so dear, I'll choose another.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why take your first man wench, and go no further.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peace Francis, hark ye sister, this I say, you know my mind, or answer I or nay, wit and judgement hath resolved his mind, and he foresees what after he shall find,
sp.l: If such discretion then shall govern you,
Vow love to him, he'll do the like to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Vow love? who would not love such a comely feature?
Nor high nor low, but of the middle stature,
A middle man that's the best size indeed,
I like him well, love grant us well to speed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And let me see a woman of that tallness,
so slender and of such a middle smallness,
So old enough, and in each part so fit,
So fair, so kind, endowed with so much wit,
Of so much wit as it is held a wonder,
'Twere pity to keep love and her asunder,
Therefore go up my joy, call down my bliss,
Bid her come seal the bargain with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Frank, Frank, I come through dangers, death and harms
To make love's patient with thy seal of arms.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But sister softly, lest my mother hear.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hush then, mum, mouse in cheese, cat is near.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now in good faith Philip this makes me smile.
That I have wooed and won in so small while.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Francis, indeed my sister I dare say,
Was not determined to say thee nay,
For this same tother thing, called maidenhead,
Hangs by so small a hair or spider's thread,
And worn so too with time, it must needs fall,
And like a well lured hawk, she knows her call.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Whist brother whist, my mother heard me tread,
And asked who's there? I would not answer her,
She called a light, and up she's gone to seek me,
There when she finds me not, she'll hither come,
Therefore dispatch, let it be quickly done,
Francis, my l●ues lease I do let to thee,
Date of my life and thine, what sayest thou to me?
The entering, fine, or income thou must pay,
Are kisses and embraces every day,
And quarterly I must receive my rent,
You know my mind.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I guess at thy intent,
Thou shalt not miss a minute of thy time.

sp.speaker: M●l.
sp.l: Why then sweet Francis I am only thine,
Brother bear witness.

sp.speaker: P●i.
sp.l: Do ye deliver this as your deed?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do I do,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: God send you both good speed, god's lord my mother
Stand aside and closely too, lest that you be espied,

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: You disobedient ruffian, careless wretch,
that said your father loud me too well,
I'll think on't when thou thinkst I have forgotten it:
Who's with thee else? how now minion you?
With whom? with him? why what make you here sir?
And thus late too, what hath your mother sent ye
To cut my throat, that here you be in wait?
Come from him mistress, and let go his hand,
Will ye not sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Stay mistress Barnes, or mother, what ye will,
She's my wife, and here she shall be still.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: How sir your wife? wouldst thou my daughter have
I'll rather have her married to her grave,
Go to be gone, and quickly, or I swear,
I'll have my men beat ye for staying here,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Beat him mother ▪ as I am true man,
They were better beat the devil and his dam.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: What wilt thou take his part?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To do him good,
And 'twere to wade hitherto up in blood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: God a mercy Phil, but mother hear me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Callest thou me mother, no thy mother's name
Carries about with it, reproach and shame:
Give me my daughter, ere that she shall wed,
A strumpet's son, and have her so misled,
I'll marry her to a carter: come I say,
Give me her from thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mather not today,
Nor yet tomorrow, till my lives last morrow,
Make me leave that, which I with leave did borrow,
Here I have borrowed love, I'll not deny it,
Thy wedding night's my day, then I'll repay it:
Till then she'll trust me, wench is't not so?
And if it be, say I, if nor, say no.

sp.speaker: M●l.
sp.l: Mother, good mother, hear me oh good God,
Now we are even what would you make us odd?
Now I beseech ye for the love of Christ,
To give me leave once to do what I list.
I am as you were when you were a maid,
Guess by yourself, how long you would have stayed,
Might you have had your will, as good begin,
at first as last, it saves us from much sin,
Lying alone, we muse on things and things,
And in our minds, one thought another brings,
This maid's life mother is an idle life,
Therefore I'll be, I, I will be wife,
And mother do not mistrust my age or power,
I am sufficient, I lack near an hour,
I had both wit to grant when he did woe me,
And strength to bear whate'er he can do to me.

sp.speaker: Master ●. Gou.
sp.l: Well bold face, but I mean to make you stay,
Go to, come from him, or I'll make ye come,
Will ye not come?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother, I pray forbear,
This match is for my sister.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Villain 'tis not,
Nor she shall not be so matched now.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: In troth she shall, and your unruly hate,
Shall not rule us, we'll end all this debate,
By this begun device.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I end what you begun, villain's thieves
Give me my daughter, will ye rob me of her?
Help, help, they'll rob me here, they'll rob me here,

div.stage: Enter master Barnes and his men.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How now, what outcry is here? why how now woman?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Why Goursey's son, confederates with this boy,
This wretch unnatural and undutiful.
Seeks hence to steal my daughter, will you suffer it?
Shall he that's son to my arch-enemy,
Enjoy her, have I brought her up to this?
O God he shall not have her, no he shall not.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I am sorry she knows it, hark ye wife,
Let reason moderate your rage a little,
If you examine but his birth and living.
His wit and good behaviour, you will say,
Though that ill hate make your opinion bad,
He doth deserve as good a wife as she

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Why will you give consent he shall enjoy her?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Ay, so that thy mind would agree with mine.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: My mind shall ne'er agree to this agreement.

sp.speaker: Master Ba.
sp.l: And yet it shall go forward, but who's here?
What, mistress Goursey, how knew she of this?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Frank, thy mother.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Swounds where? A plague upon it,
I think the devil is set to cross this match.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: This is the house Dick Coomes, and yonder's light,
Let us go near: how now, methinks I see,
My son stand hand in hand, with barns his daughter:
Why how now sirrah, is this time of night,
For you to be abroad, what have we here?
I hope that love hath not thus coupled you:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Love by my troth mother, love, she loves me,
And I love her, than we must needs agree.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I but I'll keep her sure enough from thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: It shall not need, I'll keep him safe enough,
Be sure he shall not graft in such a stock.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: What a stock forsooth? as good a stock as thine,
I do not mean that he shall graft in mine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Nor shall he mistress, hark boy? thou'rt but mad
To love the branch, that hath a root so bad,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Then mother, I'll graft a pippin on a crab.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: It will not prove well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But I'll prove my skill.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Sir but you shall not.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mother's both I will.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Hark Philip, send away thy sister straight,
Let Francis meet her where thou shalt appoint,
Let them go several to shun suspicion,
And bid them go to Oxford both this night,
There tomorrow say that we will meet them,
And there determine of their marriage.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I will, though it be very late and dark,
My sister will endure it for a husband.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Well then to Carfolke's boy, I mean to meet them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Enough, would they would begin to chide,
For I would have them brawling, that meanwhile ,
They nay steal hence, to meet where I oppoint it,
What mother, will you let this match go forward:
Or mistress Goursey will you first agree ▪

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Shall I agree first?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I why not, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Come from her son, and if thou lovest thy mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: With the like spell, daughter I conjure thee,

sp.speaker: Mistress G.
sp.l: Francis, by fair means let me win thee from her,
And I will gild my blessing gentle son,
With store of angels, I would not have thee,
Check thy good fortune, by this thy cusning choice,
Oh do not thrall thy happy liberty,
In such a bondage, if thou'lt be needs bound,
Be then to better worth, this worthless choice
Is not fit for thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Is't not fit for him, wherefore is't not fit?
Is he too brave a gentleman I pray,
No 'tis not fit, she shall not fit his turn,
If she were wise, she would be fitter for
Three times his better, minion go in, or I'll make ye,
I'll keep ye safe from him I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Come Francis, come from her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mothers, with both hands, shove I hate from love,
That like an ill companion would infect,
The infant mind of our affection,
Within this cradle shall this minute's babe,
Be laid to rest, and thus I'll huge my joy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou,
sp.l: Wilt thou be obstinate, thou self wild boy.
Nay then perforce I'll part ye since ye will not.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Do ye hear mistress, pray ye give me leave to talk two or three cold words with my young master, hark ye sir, ye are my master's son, and so forth, and indeed I bear ye some good will, partly for his sake, and partly for your own, and I do hope you do the like to me, I should be sorry else: I must needs say ye are a y●ng man, and for mine own part, I have seen the world, and I know what belongs to causes, and the experience that I have, I thank God I have travelled for it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why how far have ye travelled for it?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: From my master's house to the alehouse.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bo
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Go to I pray, correct you boy, 'twas never a good world, since a boy would face a man so,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to forward man.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Well sir, so it is, I would not wish ye to marry without my mistress consent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Nay, there's ne'er a why, but there is a wherefore, I have known some have done the like, and they have danced a galliard at beggar's bush for it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: At beggar's bush, here him no more master, he doth bedaub ye with his dirty speech: do ye hear sir, how far stands beggar's bush from your father's house sir? how thou whoreson refuge of a tailor, that wert prentice to a tailor half an age, and because if thou hadst served ten ages thou wouldst prove but a butcher, thou leap'st from the shop board to a blue coat: doth it become thee to use thy terms so? well, thou degree above a hackney, and ten degrees under a page, sow up your lubber lips, or 'tis not your sword and buckler, shall keep my poniard from your breast.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Do ye hear sir, this is your boy?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: You must breech him for it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Must I? how if I will not.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Why then 'tis a fine world, when boys keep boys, and know not how to use them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Boy, ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.p: Strike him and thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Strike me, alas he were better strike his father, 'sounds go to, put up your bodkin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mother stand by, I'll teach that rascal,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Go to, give me good words, or by gods dines I'll buckle ye, for all your bird-spit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye so sir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Stay Frank, this pitch of frenzy will defile thee,
Meddle not with it, thy unreproved valour,
Should be high minded: couch it not so low,
Dost hear me? take occasion to slip hence,
But secretly, let not thy mother see thee,
At the backside there is a coney green,
Stay there for me, and mall and I will come to thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Enough, I will: mother you do me wrong,
To be so peremptory in your command,
And see that rascal to abuse me so.

sp.speaker: Coom
sp.p: Rascal, take that and take all, do ye hear sir, I do not mean to pocket up this wrong.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I know why that is.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Because you have ne'er a pocket,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: A whip sirrah, a whip: but sir provide your tools against tomorrow morning 'tis somewhat dark now indeed, you know Dawson's close, between the hedge and the pond, 'tis good even ground, I'll meet you there, and I do not, call me cut, and you be a man show yourself a man, we'll have a bout or two, and so we'll part for that present.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well sir, well.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Boy, have they appointed to fight?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I Nicholas, wilt not thou go see the fray?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: No indeed, even as they brew so let them bake. I will not thrust my hand into the flame and need not, 'tis not good to have an oar in another man's boat, little said is soon amended, and in little meddling cometh great rest, 'tis good sleeping in a whole skin, so a man might come home by weeping cross: no by lady, a friend is not so soon gotten as lost, blessed are the peacemakers, they that strike with the sword, shall be beaten with the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well said proverbs, near another to that purpose?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes I could have said to you sir, take heed is a good reed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why to me take heed?

sp.speaker: Ni,
sp.p: For happy is he whom other men's harms do make to beware.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O beware Frank, slip away mall, you know what I told ye, I'll hold our mothers both in talk meanwhile : mother and mistress barns, methinks you should not stand in hatred so hard one with the other.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Should I not sir 'Should I not hate a harlot,
That robs me of my right, vide boy?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: That title I return unto thy teeth,
And spit the name of harlot in thy face.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Well 'tis not time of night to hold out chat,
With such a scold as thou art, therefore now,
Think that I hate thee as I do the devil.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: The devil take thee if thou dost not wretch.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Out upon thee strumpet.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Out upon thee harlot.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Well, I will find a time to be revenged:
mean time I'll keep my daughter from thy son,
Where are you minion? how now are ye gone.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She went in mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Francis where are ye?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: He is not here ▪ o then they split away and both together.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'll assure ye no, my sister she went in, into the house,

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: But then she'll out again at the back door,
And meet with him, but I will search about,
All these same fields and paths near to my house,
They are not far I am sure, if I make haste,

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: O God how went he hence? I did not see him,
It was when Barnes wife did scold with me,
A plague on her, Dick why didst not thou look to him?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: What should I look for him? no, no, I look not for him while tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Come go with me to help to look him out,
Alas, I have nor light, nor link, nor torch,
Though it be dark, I will take any pains,
To cross this match, I prithee Dick away.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Mistress because I brought ye out, I'll bring ye home but if I should follow, so he might have the law on his side.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go
sp.l: Come 'tis no matter, prithee go with me.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Philip thy mothers gone to seek thy sister.
And in a rage i'faith, but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Old master Goursey, as I think 'tis he.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: 'Tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: A friend of yours.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: What master Barnes did ye not see my wife?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Yes sir I saw her, she was here even now.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: I doubted that, that made me come unto you:
But whether is she gone?

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: To seek your son, who slipped away from her,
To meet with mall my sister in a place
Where I appointed: and my mother too,
Seek for my sister, so they both are gone,
My mother hath a torch, marry your wife
Goes darkling up and down, and Coomes before her.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I thought that knave was with her, but 'tis well,
I pray God they may come by never a light,
but both be led a dark dance in the night.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Why is my fellow Dick in the dark with my mistress. I pray God they be honest, for there may be much knavery in the dark, faith if I were there, I would have some knavery with them, good master will ye carry the torch yourself, and give me leave to play the blind man buff with my mistress,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On that condition thou wilt do thy best,
To keep thy mistress and thy fellow Dick,
Both from my sister, and thy master's son,
I will entreat thy master let thee go.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: O ay, I warrant ye, I'll have fine tricks to cozen them

sp.speaker: Master Gou.
sp.l: Well sir, then go your ways, I give you leave.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: O brave, but where about are they?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: About our coney green they surely are, if thou canst find them.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: O let me alone to grope for coneys.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Well, now will I to Frank and to my sister,
Stand you two harkening near the coney green,
But sure your light in you must not be seen,
Or else let Nicholas stand afar off with it,
And as his life keep it from mistress Goursey,
Shall this be done?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Philip it shall,

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.l: God be with ye, I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Come on master Goursey, this fame is a means,
To make our wives friends, if they resist not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Go.
sp.l: T●t sir, howsoever it shall go forward.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Come then let● do, as Philip hath advised.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here is the place where Philip bid me stay,
Till Francis came, but wherefore did my bother,
Appoint i● here? why in the coney borough?
He had some meaning in't I warrant ye,
Well here I'll set me down under this tree,
And think upon the matter all alone,
Good lord what pretty things these coneys are,
How finely they do feed till they be fat,
And then what a sweet meat a coney is,
And what smooth skins they have, both black and grey,
They say they run more in the night than day,
What is the reason? mark, why in the light,
They see more passengers than in the night,
for harmful men many a hay do set.
And laugh to see them tumble in the net,
And they put ferrets in the holes, fie, fie,
And they go up and down where conies lie,
And they lie still, they have so little wit,
I marvel the warrener will suffer it,
Nay, nay, they are so bad, that they themselves,
Do give consent to catch these pretty elves,
How if the warrener should spy me here?
He would take me for a coney I dare swear,
But when that Francis comes, what will he say?
Look boy there lies a coney in my way:
But soft, a light, who's that? should my mother,
Nay then all hid, i'faith she shall not see me,
I'll play bo peep with her behind this tree.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: I marvel where this wench doth hide herself
So closely? I have searched in many a bush,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Belike my mother took me for a thrush,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: She's hid in this same warren I'll lay money.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Close as a rabbit sucker from an old coney.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: O God, I would to God that I could find her,
I would keep her from her love's toys yet.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I so you might, if your daughter had no wit.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: What a vild gi●le 'tis, that would have't so young.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A murrain take that dissembling tongue,
Ere your calf's teeth were out you thought it long.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: But minion, yet I'll keep you from the man.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: To save a lie mother, say if you can.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Well, now to look for her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I there's the spite,
What trick shall I now have to scape her light?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Who's there? what minion is it you?
Beshrew her heart, what a fright she put me to,
But I am glad I found her, though I was afraid,
Come on your ways, you are a handsome maid,
Why you forth a doors so late at night?
Why whether go ye? come stand still I say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No indeed mother, this is my best way.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: 'Tis not the best way, stand by me I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Mall .
sp.l: No you would catch me mother, oh I smell ye.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Will ye not stand still?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No by lady no.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: But I will make ye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay then trip and go.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Mistress, I'll make ye weary ere I have done.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Faith mother then I'll try how you can run,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Will ye?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes faith.
Mal. sweet heart, Mal●? what not a word?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A little further, call again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why mal. I prithee speak, why mal I say?
I know thou art not far, if thou wilt not speak, why mal,
But now I see she's in her merry vain,
To make me call and put me to more pain,
Well, I must bear with her, she'll bear with me,
But I will call, lest that it be not so,
What mall? what mall I say, boy are we right?
Have we not missed the way this same dark night?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Mass it may be so as I am true man,
I have not seen a coney since I came,
Yet at the cunny-borow we should meet,
But hark, I hear the trampling of some feet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It may be so, then therefore let's lie close.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Where art thou Dick?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Where am I quoth 'a, marry I may be where anybody will say I am, either in France or at Rome, or at Jerusalem they may say I am, for I am not able to disprove them, because I cannot tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: O what a blindfold walk have we had Dick,
To seek my son and yet I cannot find him?

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: Why then mistress let's go home.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Why 'tis so dark we shall not find the way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I pray God ye may not mother till it be day.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: 'Sblood take heed mistress here's a tree.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Lead thou the way, and let me hold by thee,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Dick Coomes, what difference is there between a blind man, and he that cannot see?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Peace, a pox on thee.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: 'Swounds somebody spoke.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Dick look about,
It may be here we may find them out.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.l: I see the glimpse of somebody here,
And ye be a sprite I'll fray the bug bear,
There 'a goes mistress.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.l: O sir have I spied you?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A plague on the boy, 'twas he that descried me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How like a beauteous lady masked in black,
Looks that same large circumference of heaven,
The sky that was so fair three hours ago,
Is in three hours become an Aethiop,
And being angry at her beauteous change,
She will not have one of those pearled stars,
To blab her sable metamorphosis,
'Tis very dark, I did appoint my sister,
To meet me at the coney berry below,
And Francis too, but neither can I see,
Belike my mother happened on that place.
And frayed them from it, and they both are now
Wand'ring about the fields, how shall I find them?
It is so dark, I scarce can see my hand,
Why then I'll hollow for them, no not so,
So will his voice betray him to our mothers,
And if he answer, and bring them where he is.
What shall I then do? it must not be so?
'Sblood it must be so, how else I pray?
Shall I stand gaping here all night till day?
And then never the near, so ho, so ho.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho, I come, where are ye? where art thou? here.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: How now Frank, where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Frank, what Frank? 'sblood is sir Raph mad, here's the bow.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have not been much private with that voice,
Methink Frank Goursey's talk and his doth tell me,
I am mistaken, especially by his bow,
Frank had no bow, well, I will leave this fellow,
And hollow somewhat farther in the fields,
Dost thou hear fellow, I perceive by thee,
That we are both mistaken, I took thee,
For one thou art not, likewise thou tookst me,
For sir Raph smith, but sure I am not he,
And so farewell, I must go seek my friend, so ho:

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho, so ho, nay then sir Raph so whore,
for a whore she was sure, if you had her here
So late, now you are sir Raphe smith,
Well do ye counterfeit and change your voice,
But yet I know ye, but what should be that Francis?
Belike that Francis cozened him of his wench,
And he conceals himself to find her out,
'Tis so upon my life, well I will go
And help him ring his peal of so ho, soho,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A plague on Coomes, a plague upon the boy ▪
A plague too, not on my mother for an hundreth bound,
'Twas time to run, and yet I had not thought
My mother could have followed me so close,
Her legs with age I thought had foundered,
She made me quite run through a quickset hedge,
Or she had taken me: well I may say,
I have run through the briers for a wench,
And yet I have her not, the worse luck mine,
Methought I heard one hollow here about,
I judge it Philip, oh the slave will laugh
Whenas he hears how that my mother scared me,
Well, here I'll stand until I hear him hollow,
And then I'll answer him, he is not far.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My man is hollowing for me up and down,
And yet I cannot meet with him, so ho:

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why what a pox wert thou so near me man,
And would not speak?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Sblood ye are very hot.

sp.speaker: Rap
sp.l: No sir, I am cold enough with staying here
For such a knave as you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Knave, how now Philip, art mad, art mad?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why art not thou my man.
That went to fetch my bow,
Indeed a bow,
Might shoot me ten bows down the weather so,
● your man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: What art thou then?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A man, but what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Some call me Raph.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Well said familiar will, plain Raph i'faith,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There calls my man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But there goes mine away.
And yet I'll hear what this next call will say,
And here I'll tarry till he call again.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So ho, where art thou Philip,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: 'Sblood Philip,
But now he called me Francis, this is fine

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why studiest thou? I prithee tell me Philip.
Where the wench is.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Even now he asked me Francis for the wench,
And now he ask me Philip for the wench,
Well sir Raph. I must needs tell ye now,
'Tis not for your credit to be forth,
So late a wenching in this order

sp.speaker: Fra●.
sp.l: What's this, so late a wenching doth he say?
Indeed 'tis true, I am thus late a wenching,
But I am forced to wench without a wench.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why then you might have ta'en your bow at first,
And gone and killed a buck, and not have been
So long a drabbing, and be ne'er the near.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Swounds what a pussel am I in this night,
But yet I'll put this fellow farther,
Dost thou hear man? I am not sir Raph smith.
As thou dost think I am, but I did meet him,
Even as thou sayest in pursuit of a wench.
I met the wench to, and asked for thee,
Saying 'twas thou that wert her love, her dear,
And that sir Raph was not an honest knight,
To train her thither, and to use her so.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: 'Sblood my wench, 'swounds were he ten sir raphs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay 'tis true, look to it, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Indeed I do love Nan our dairy maid,
And hath he train her forth to that intent?
Or for another, I carry his crossbow,
And he doth cross me, shooting in my bow,
What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: So ho,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Francies art thou there?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No here's no Francis, art thou will my man?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Will fool your man, will goose your man,
My back sir scorns to wear your livery.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Nay sir I moved but such a question to you,
Had it hath not disparaged you I hope,
'Twas but mistaking, such a night as this
May well deceive a man, God boy sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: God's will 'tis sir Raph smith, a virtuous knight,
How gently entertains he my hard answer?
Rude anger made my tongue unmannerly,
I cry him mercy, well, but all this while,
I cannot find a Francis, Francis ho?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Francis ho ▪ oh you call Francis now,
How have ye used my Nan? come tell me how?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy Nan, what Nan?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Ay, what Nan now, say, do you not seek a wench?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes I do.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Then sir that is she.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Art not thou I met withal before?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Yes sir, and you did counterfeit before,
And said to me you were not sir Raph smith,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No more I am not, I met sir Raph smith,
Even now he asked me if I saw his man.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: O fine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why sirrah thou art much deceived in me,
Good faith I am not he thou thinkst I am.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What are ye then?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why one that seeks one Francis and a wench.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And Francis seeks one Philip and a wench:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I met him seeking Philip and a wench,
As I was seeking sir Raph and a wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why then I know the matter, we met cross,
And so we missed, now here we find our loss,
Well, if thou wilt, we two will keep together,
And so we shall meet right with one or other,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am content, but do you hear me sir?
Did not sir Raph smith ask ye for a wench?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: No I promise thee, nor did he look for any
But thyself, as I could guess.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.l: Why this is strange, but come sir let's away,
I fear that we shall walk here till it be day.

sp.speaker: Enter boy.
sp.p: O God I have run so far into the wind, that I have run myself out of wind, they say a man is near his end when he lacks breath, and I am at the end of my race, for I can run no farther than here I be in my breath bed, not in my death bed.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: They say men moil and toil for a poor living, so I moil and toil, and am living I thank God, in good time be it spoken, it had been better for me my mistress angel had been light, for then perhaps it had not led me into this darkness, well, the devil never blesses a man better, when he purses up angels by owlight, I ran through a hedge to take the boy but I stuck in the ditch, and lost the boy: 'swounds a plague on that clod, that molehill, that ditch, or what the devil soe'er it were, for a man cannot see what it was, well, I would not for the prize of my sword and buckler, anybody should see me in this taking for it would make me but cut off their legs for laughing at me, well, down I am, and down I mean to be, because I am weary, but to tumble down thus, it was no part of my meaning, then since I am down, here I'll rest me, and no man shall remove me.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: O I have sport in coney i'faith, I have almost burst myself with laughing at mistress barns, she was following of her daughter, and I hearing her, put on my fellow Dickes sword and bucklers voice, and his swoons and 'sblood words, and led her such a dance in the dark as it passes, here she is quoth I, where quoth she? here quoth I, oh it hath been a brave here and there night, but oh what a soft natured thing the dirt is? how it would endure my hard treading, and kiss my feet for acquaintance, and how courteous and mannerly were the clods, to make me stumble only of purpose to entreat me lie down and rest me, but now and I could find my fellow Dick, I would play the knave with him honestly i'faith, well, I will grope in the dark for him, or I'll poke with my staff like a blind man, to prevent a ditch.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Who's that with a pox?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Who art thou with a pestilence.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Why I am Dick Coomes?

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: What have I found thee Dick? nay then I am for ye Dick, where are ye Dick?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: What can I tell where I am?

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Can ye not tell, come, come ye weight on your mistress well, come on your ways, I have sought you till I am weary, and called ye till I am hoarse, good lord what a jaunt I have had this night, heigh ho?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Is't you mistress that came over me, 'sblood 'twere a good deed to come over you for this night's work, I cannot afford all this pains for an angel I tell ye true a kiss were not cast away upon a good fellow, that hath deserved more that way then a kiss, if your kindness would afford it him, what shall I have it mistress?

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I must not kiss my man.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Nay ▪ nay, ne'er stand, shall I, shall I, nobody sees, say but I shall, and I'll smack ye soundly i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Away bawdy man, in truth I'll tell your master.

sp.speaker: Coom
sp.p: My master, go to, near tell me of my master, he may pray for them that may, he is past it, and for mine own part, I can do somewhat that way I thank God, I am not now to learn, and 'tis your part to have your whole desire.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I am ashamed of you, would you tempt your mistress to lewdness.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: To lewdness, no by my troth there's no such matter in't, it is for kindness, and by my troth if you like my gentle offer, you shall have what courteously I can afford ye.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Shall I indeed Dick? I'faith, if I thought nobody would see.

sp.speaker: Coom
sp.p: ●ush, fear not that, 'swounds they must have cats eyes then,

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Then kiss me dick.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: A kind wench i'faith, where are ye mistress?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Here Dick, oh I am in the dark, Dick go about,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Nay, I'll grope sure, where are ye. Hodge. Here,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: A plague on this post, I would the carpenter had been hanged that set it up so, where are ye now?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Coo,
sp.p: Here, oh I come, a plague on it, I am in a pond mistress.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I have led him into a pond, where art thou Dick?

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p: Up to the middle in a pond.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Make a boat of thy buckler then, and swim out, are ye so hot with a pox? would you kiss my mistress, cool ye there then good dick Coomes, oh when he comes forth the skirts of his blue coat will drop like a paint-house, oh that I could see and not be seen, how he would spaniel it, and shake himself when he comes out of the pond, but I'll be gone, for now he'll fight with a fly, if he but buzz in his ear.

sp.speaker: Coom
sp.p: Here's so hoing with a plague, so hang and ye will for I have been almost drowned, a pox of your lips, and ye call this kissing: ye talk of a drownd rat, but 'twas time to swim like a dog I had been served like a drownd cattles, I would he had digged his grave that digged the pond, my feet were foul indeed, but a les●e pale than a pond would have served my turn to wash them: a man shall be served thus always, when he follows any of these females but 'tis my kind heart that makes me thus forward in kindness unto them, well God amend them, and make them thankful to them that would do them pleasure I am not drunk I would ye should know it, and yet I have drunk more than will do me good, for I might have had a pump set up, with as good march beer as this was, and never set up an ale bush 'For the matter: well I am somewhat in wroth I must needs say, and yet I am not more angry than wise, nor more wise than angry, but I'll fight with the next man I mere, and it be but for luck's sake, and if he love to see himself hurt, let him bring light with him, I'll do it by darkling else by gods dines, well here will I walk whosoever says nay.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
He that worse may must hold the candle, but my master is not so wise as God might have made him, he is gone to seek a hair in a hen's nest, a needle in a bottle of hay, which is as seldom seen as a black swan: he is gone to seek my young mistress, and I think she is better lost than found, for whosoever hath her, hath but a wet eel by the tail, but they may do as they list, the law is in their own hands, but and they would be rvid●y me, they should set her on the Leland, and b●d the devil sp●● her, beshrew her fingers, she hath made me watch passed mine
hour, but I'll watch her a good turn for it.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: How, who's that Nicholas? so first come first served, I am for him: how now proverb, proverb, 'sblood how now proverb?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My name is Nicholas, Richard: and I know your meaning, and I hope ye mean no harm: I thank ye I am the better for your asking.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Where have you been a whoring thus late, ha?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Master Richard the good wife would not seek her daughter in the oven unless she had been there herself, but good lord you are knuckle deep in dirt, I warrant when he was in, he swore Walsingham, and chafed terrible for the time, look the water drops from you as fast as hops.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: What needst thou to care, whipper-jenny, tripecheeks, out you fat ass.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Good words cost naught, ill words corrupts good manners Richard, for a hasty man never wants woe, and I had thought you had been my friend, but I see all is not gold that glisters, there's falsehood in fellowship, a micus certus in re cer ta cernitur, time and truth tries all, and 'tis an old proverb, and not so old as true, bought wit is best, I can see day at a little hole, I know your mind as well as though I were within you, 'tis ill halting before a cripple, go to, you seek to quarrel but be ware of had I wist: so long goes the pot to the water at length it comes home broken, I know you are as good a man as ever drew sword, or as was ere girt ina girdle, or as ere went on neat's leather, or as one shall see upon a summer's day, or as ere looked man in the face, or as ere trodden on god's earth, or as ere broke bread, or drunk drink: but he is proper that hath proper conditions, but be not like the cow that gives a good soap of milk and casts it down with her heels, I speak plainly, for plain dealing is a jewel, and he that useth it shall die a beggar, well, that happens in an hour, that happens not in seven years, a man is not so soon whole as hurt and you should kill a man, you would kiss him: well, I say little, but I think the more, yet I'll give him good words, 'tis good to hold a candle before the devil, yet by god's me, I'll take no wrong, if he had a head as big as brass, or looked as high as Poule's steeple.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p:
Sirrah, thou grasshopper, that shalt skip from my sword
as from a sith, I'll cut thee out in collops and eggs, in sleeks, in sliced beef, and fry thee with the fire, I shall strike from the pike of they buckler.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ay, brag's a good dog, threatened folks live long.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: What say ye sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why I say not so much as how do ye.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Do ye not so sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No indeed, whatsoe'er I think, and thought is free.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: You whoreson wafer-cake, by gods dines I'll crush ye for this.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Give an inch and you'll take an ell, I will not put my finger in a hole I warrant ye, what man, ne'er crow so fast, for a blind man may kill a hare, I have known when ● plain fellow hath hurt a fencer, so I have: what, a man may be as slow as a snail, but as fierce as a lion, and he be moved: indeed I am patient I must needs say, for patience in adversity, brings a man to the three cranes in the ventree.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Do ye hear, set down your torch, draw, fight, I am for ye.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: And I am for ye too, though it be from this midnight to the next morn.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Where be your tools?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Within a mile of an oak sir, he's a proud horse will not carry his own provender, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Now am I in my quarrelling humour, and now can I say nothing but sownes draw, but I'll untruss, and then have to it.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Who's there, boy? honest boy, well met, where hast thou been.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Hodge, Dick Coomes hath been as good as a cry of hounds, to make a breathed hair of me, but didst thou see my master?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: I met him even now, and he asked me for thee, and he is gone up and down, hooing like an owl for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Owl, ye ass.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Ass, no nor glass, for then it had been owlglass, but who's that boy?

sp.speaker: Bo ▪
sp.p: By the mass 'tis our Coomes and Nicholas, and it seems they are providing to fight.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Then we shall have fine sport, i'faith sirrah, let's stand close, and when they have fought about or two, we'll run away with the torch, and leave them to fight darkling, shall we?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Content, I'll get the torch, stand close.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: So now my back hath room to reach, I do not love to be laced in, when I go to lace a rascal, I pray God Nicholas prove not a fly: it would do me good to deal with a good man now, that we might have half a dozen good smart strokes, ha I have seen the day, I could have danced in my fight, on, two, three four and five, ou the head of him six, seven, eight, nine and ten, on the sides of him, and if I went so far as fifteen, I warrant I showed him a trick of one and twenty: but I have not sought this four days, and I lack a little practice of my war●e, but I shall make a shift, ha close, are ye disposed sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes indeed I fear no colours, change sides Richard.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Change the gallows, I'll see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Well, I see the fool will not leave his babble for the tower of London.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Fool ye rogue, nay then fall to it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Good goose bite not.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: 'Sblood how pursy I am, well I see exercise is all, I must practise my weapons oftener, I must have a goal or two at football, before I come to my right kind, give me thy hand Nicholas, thou art a better man than I took thee for, and yet thou art not so good a man as I.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You dwell by● neighbours Richard, that makes ye praise yourself.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Why I hope thou wilt say I am a man.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Yes I'll say so if I should see you hanged.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p: Hanged ye rogue, nay then have at ye, swoons the light is gone.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: O lord, it is as dark as pitch,

sp.speaker: Coo,
sp.p: Well here I'll lie with my buckler thus, lest striking up and down at randall, the rogue might hurt me, for I cannot see to save it, and I'll hold my peace, lest my voice should bring them where I am.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis good. O have a cloak for the rain, a bad shift is better than none at all, I'll sit here as if I were as dead as a door nail.

div.stage: Enter m. barns and m. Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Hark, there's one holloes.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And there's another.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: And everywhere we come, I here some hollo. And yet it is our haps to meet with none.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I marvel where your Hodge is, and my man?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: I and our wives, we cannot meet with them.
Nor with the boy, nor mall, nor Frank, nor Philip:
Nor yet with Coomes, and yet we ne'er stood still.
Well I am very angry with my wife,
And she shall find I am not pleased with her,
If we meet never so soon, but 'tis my hap,
She hath had as blind a journey out as we,
Pray God she have, and worse if worse may be.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: This is but short lived envy master curtsy:
But come, what say ye to my policy?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I'faith 'tis good, and we will practise it,
But sir it must be handled cunningly,
Or all is marred, our wives have subtle heads,
And they will soon perceive a drift device.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Master Gour.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Here's on or two.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Is will there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: No, Philip?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Frank?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: No, no.
Was ever man deluded thus like me,
I think some spirit leads me thus amiss:
As I have often heard, that some have been thus in the nights.
But yet this mazes me where ere I come,
Some asks me still for Frank or Philip,
And none of them can tell me where will is.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.l: So ho!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: 'Sounds now I here four hollow at the least,
One had a little voice, then that's the wench
My man hath lost, well I will answer all, so ho.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.l: Whope, whope.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Who's there will?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: No sir, honest Hodge: but I pray ye sir did ye not meet with a boy with a torch, he is run away from me a plague on him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Hey day, from Frank and Philip to a torch,
And to a boy, nay 'sounds then hap as 'twill.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Gesse here.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Philip.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Philip, no faith, my names will, ill will, for I was never worse, I was even now with him, and might have been still, but that I fell into a ditch and lost him, and now I am going up and down to seek him.

sp.speaker: M. Gor.
sp.p: What wouldst thou do with him.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why I would have him go with me to my masters.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.p: Whose thy master?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why sir Raphe smith, and thither he promised me he would come, if he keep his word so 'tis.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.p: What was he a doing when thou first found him.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why he holloed for one Francis, and Francis holloa'd for him, I hallowed for my master, and my master for me, but we missed still meeting contrary, Philip and Francis with me and my master, and I and my master with Philip and Frank.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.p: Why wherefore is sir Raphe so late abroad?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why he meant to kill a buck, I'll say so to save his honesty, but my Nan was his mark, and when he sent me for his bow, and when I came, I holloa'd for him, but I never saw such luck to miss him, it hath almost made me mad.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well stay with us, perhaps sir Raphe and he,
Will come anon, hark I do here one hollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this broad waking in a winter's night,
I am broad walking in a winter's night:
Broad indeed, because I am abroad,
But these broad fields methinks are not so broad,
That they may keep me forth of narrow ditches,
Here's a hard world for I can hardly keep myself upright in it,
I am marvelous dutiful, but so ho.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Here's will.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What will, how scap'st thou?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay, not hanging, but drowning,
Wert thou in a pond or a ditch?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: A pestilence on it, is't you Philip, no faith, I was but dirty a little, but here's one or two asked for ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who be they man?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Philip, 'tis I and master Goursey.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Father, oh father I have heard them say.
The days of ignorance are past and done,
But I am sure the nights of ignorance
Are not yet past, for this is one of them,
But where's my sister?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why we cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Where's Francis?

sp.speaker: Master Gour.
sp.l: Neither saw we him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why this is fine.
What neither he, nor I, nor she nor you,
Nor I, nor she, nor you, and I will now,
Can meet, could meet, or never I think shall meet,
Call ye this ●oing, no 'tis Christmas sport of Hob man blind
All blind, all seek to catch, all miss: but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O have I catched ye sir, it was your doing,
That made me have this pretty dance tonight ,
Had not you speak, my mother had not scared me,
But I will swinge ye for it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Keep the King's peace,

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: How? art thou become a constable?
Why Philip where hast thou been all this while?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why where you were not, but I pray where's my sister?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why man I saw her not, but I have sought her as I should seek.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A needle have ye not?
Why you man are the needle that she seeks
To work withal, well Francis do you here,
You must not answer so, that you have sought her,
But have ye found her, faith and if you have,
God give ye joy of that ye found with her,
Fra I saw her not, how could I find her.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why, could ye miss form master Barnses house unto his Cunny-berry?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Whether I could or no, father I did.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Father I did, well Frank wilt thou believe me,
Thou dost not know how much this same doth grieve me
Shall it be said thou missed so plain away,
Whenas so fair a wench did for thee stay.

sp.speaker: Fra,
sp.l: 'Sounds man.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Sounds man, and if thou hadst been blind,
the cunny-borow thou needst must find:
I tell thee Francis had it been my case,
And I had been a wooer in thy place,
I would have laid my head unto the ground,
And scented out my wench's way like a hound:
I would have crept upon my knees all night,
And have made the flint stones links to give me light,
Nay man I would.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good lord what you would do,
Well we shall see one day how you can woe.

sp.speaker: M. Go●.
sp.l: Come, come, we see that we have all been crossed.
Therefore let's go, and seek them we have lost.
Am I alone? doth not my mother come?
Her torch I see not, which I well might see,
If any way she were coming towards me,
Why then belike she's gone some other way,
And may she go till I bid her turn,
Far shall her way be then, and little fair,
For she hath hindered me of my good turn,
God send her wet and weary ere the turn,
I had been at Oxenford, and tomorrow,
Have been released from all my maiden's sorrow.
And tasted joy, had not my mother been,
God I beseech thee make it her worst sin,
How many maids this night lies in their beds,
And dream that they have lost their maidenheads,
Such dreams, such slumbers I had to enjoy,
If waking malice had not them destroyed,
A starved man with double death doth die,
To have the meat might save him in his eye,
And may not have it so am I tormented,
To starve for joy I see yet am prevented,
Well Frank, although thou wooed'st and quickly won,
Yet shall my love to thee be never done,
I'll run through hedge and ditch, through brakes and briers
To come to thee, sole lord of my desires,
Short wooing is the best, an hour, not years,
For long debating love is full of fears,
But heark, I hear one tread, o wert my brother,
Or Frank, or any man, but not my mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Rap.
sp.l: O when will this same year of night have end?
Long looked for day's sun, when wilt thou ascend?
Let not this these friend misty vale of night,
Encroach on day, and shadow thy fair light,
Whilst thou comest tardy from my Thete's bed,
Blushing forth golden hair and glorious red,
Oh stay not long bright lantern of the day,
To light my mist way feet to my right way?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: It is a man, his big voice tells me so,
Much am I not acquainted with it though,
And yet mine ear sounds true distinguisher,
Boys that I have been more familiar,
With it then now I am, well, I do judge,
It is not envy's felon not of grudge,
Therefore I'll plead acquaintance, higher his guiding,
And buy of him some place of close abiding,
Till that my mother's malice be expired,
And we may joy in that is long desired, whoses there?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Are ye a maid? no question this is she,
My man doth miss, faith since she lights on me,
I do not mean till day to let her go,
For what she is my man's love I will know,
Hark ye maid, if maid, are ye so light,
That you can see to wander in the night.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hark ye true man, if true, I tell you no,
I cannot see at all which way I go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Fair maid is't so, say had ye ne'er a fall,

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Fair man not so, no I had none at all.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Could you not stumble on one man I pray?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, no, such block till now came in my way.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Am I that block sweet tripe, then fall and try.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The grounds too hard, a featherbed, not I.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why how and you had met with such a stump?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why if he had been your height I meant to jump?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Are ye so nimble?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nimble as a doe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Backed in a pie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Of ye.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good meat ye know.

sp.speaker: Mal ▪
sp.l: Ye hunt sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What take ye?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Dear.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: You'll ne'er strike rascal?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes when ye art there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Will ye strike me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, will ye strike again?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No sir, it fits not maids to fight with men.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I wonder wench, how I thy name might know.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Why you may find it in the Christcross row.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Be my schoolmistress, teach me how to spell it.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No faith, I care not greatly if I tell it,
My name is marie Barnes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: How wench, mall Barnes?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Why this is strange.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I pray sir what's your name?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Why sir Raph smith doth wonder wench at this
Why what's the cause thou art abroad so late?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What sir Raph smith, nay then I will disclose,
All the whole cause to him, in him repose,
My hopes, my love, God him I hope did send,
Our loves and both our mothers hates to end,
Gentle sir Raph if you my blush might see,
You then would say I am ashamed to be
Found like a wand'ring stray by such a knight,
So far from home at such a time of night,
But my excuse is good, love first by fate
Is crossed, controlled, and sundered by fell hate,
Frank Goursey is my love, and he loves me,
But both our mother's hate and disagree,
Our fathers like the match, and wish it done,
And so it had, had not our mothers come,
To Oxford we concluded both to go,
Going to meet, they came, we parted so,
My mother followed me, but I ran fast,
Thinking who went from hate had need make haste,
Take me she cannot though she still pursue,
But now sweet knight, I do repose on you.
Be you my orator and plead my right,
And get me one good day for this bad night.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Alas good heart, I pity thy hard hap,
And I'll employ all that I may for thee,
Frank Goursey wench, I do commend thy choice,
Now I remember I met one Francis
As I did seek my man, then that was he,
And Philip too, belike like that was thy brother, why now I
find how I did lose myself, and wander up and down, mistaking
So, give me thy hand Mall, I will never leave.
Till I have made your mother's friends again,
And purchased to ye both your hearts delight,
And for this same one bad, many a good night,
'Twill not be long ere that Aurora will.
Decked in the glory of a golden sun,
Open the crystal windows of the East,
To make the earth enamoured of thy face,
When we shall have clear light to see our way,
Come, night being done, expect a happy day.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba
sp.l: O what a race this peevish girl hath led me?
How fast I ran and now how weary I am,
I am so out of breath I scarce can speak.
What shall I do? and cannot overtake her,
It is late and dark, and I am far from home.
May there not thieves lie watching here about,
Intending mischief unto them they meet,
There may, and I am much afraid of them,
Being alone without all company,
I do repent me of my coming forth,
And yet I do not, they had else been married,
And that I would not for ten times more labour.
But what a winter of cold fear I stole,
Freezing my heart lest danger should betide me,
What shall I do to purchase company?
I hear some hollow here about the fields,
Then here I'll set my torch upon this hill,
Whose light shall beacon-like conduct them to it,
They that have lost their way seeing a light,
Will come to it, well, here I'll lie unseen,
For it may be seen far off in the night,
And look who comes, and choose my company,
Perhaps my daughter may first come to it.

sp.speaker: Mr Gour.
sp.l: Where am I now? nay where was I ever now,
Nor now, nor then, nor where I shall be, know I,
I think I am going home I may as well
Be going from home, 'tis so very dark,
I cannot see how to direct a step,
I lost my pursuing of my son,
My son escaped me too, now all alone,
I am enforced to wander up and down,
Barnes' wife's abroad pray God that she:
May have as good a dance, nay ten times worse,
O but I fear she hath not, she hath light
To see her way, oh that some bridge would break
That she might fall into some deep digged ditch,
And either break her bones or drown herself,
I would these mischiefs I could wish to her,
Might light on her, but soft I see a light,
I will go near, 'tis comfortable,
After this nights sad spirits dulling darkness,
How now? What is it set to keep itself?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: A plague on't, is she there?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: O how it cheers and quickens up my thoughts,

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: O that it were the basilisk's fell eye,
To poison thee.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: I care not if I take it.
Sure none is here to hinder me,
And light me home.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I had rather she were hanged.
Then I should set it there to do her good.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: I'faith you shall not mistress.
I'll venture a burned finger but I'll have it.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Yet Barnes' wife would chafe if that she knew,
That I had this good to get a light.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: And so she doth, but praise you luck at parting.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: O that it were her light good faith, that she,
Might darkling walk about as well as I.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: O how this mads me, that she hath her wish,

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: How I would laugh to see her tro● about.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar
sp.l: O, I could cry for anger and for rage.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: But who should set it here I marvel a god's name?

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: One that will ha't from you in the devil's name

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: I'll lay my life that it was Barnses son.

sp.speaker: Mr Ba.
sp.l: No forsooth, it was Barnses wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou,
sp.l: A plague upon her, how she made me start?
Mistress let go the torch,

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: No but I will not.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: I'll thrust it in thy face then.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: But you shall not.

sp.speaker: Mr Gou.
sp.l: Let go I say.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Let you go, for 'tis mine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: But my possession says it is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Nay, I have hold too,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Well, let go thy hold, or I will spurn thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Do, I can spurn thee too.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Canst thou?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: I that I can.

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: Why how now woman, how unlike to women,
Are ye both now? come part, come part I say.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Why what immodesty it this in you?
Come part I say, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Mr Ba.
sp.l: Fie, fie, she shall not have my torch,
Give me thy torch boy, I will run a tilt,
And burn out both her eyes in my encounter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Give room and let's have this hat carerie.

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: I say ye shall not, wife go to, tame your thoughts,
That are so mad with fury.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: And sweet wife,
Temper you rage with patience, do not be
Subject so much to such misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar
sp.l: Shall I not sir, when such a strumpet wrongs me?

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: How, strumpet mistress barns, nay I pray hark ye,
I oft indeed have heard you call her so,
And I have thought upon it, why ye should
Twither with name of strumpet,
Do you know any hurt by her, that you term her so?

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: No on my life, rage only makes her say so,

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: But I would know whence this same rage should come.
Where's smoke there's fire, and my heart misgives.
My wife's intemperance hath got that name,
And mistress barns, I doubt and shrewdly doubt,
And some great cause begets this doubt in me,
Your husband and my wife doth wrong us both.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: How? think ye so, nay master Goursey then
you run indebt to my opinion,
Because you pay not such advised wisdom,
As I think due unto my good conceit.

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: Then still I fear I shall your debtor prove.
Then I arrest you in the name of love,
Not bale, but present answer to my plea,
And in the court of reason we will try,
If that good thoughts should believe jealousy,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why look you mother, this is long of you,
For god's sake father hark, why these effects
Come still from women's malice, part I pray,
Comes, Will. and Hodge come all and help us part them,
Father, but hear me speak one word no more:

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Father, but hear me speak, the use your will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Cry peace between ye for a little while.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Good husband hear him speak.

sp.speaker: M●s. Ba.
sp.l: Good husband hear him ▪

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p: Master hear him speak, he's a good wise young stripling, for his years I tell ye, and perhaps may speak wiser than an elder body, therefore hear him.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p: Master hear and make an end, you may kill one another in jest, and be hanged in earnest.

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: Come let us hear him, then speak quickly Philip

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have done ere this, speak

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Speak

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: O lord what haste you make to hurt yourselves
Good Philip use some good persuasions
To make them friends.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, I'll do what I can,
Father and master Goursey both attend,
It is presumption in so young a man,
To teach where he might learn or be derect,
Where he hath had direction but in duty.
He may persuade as long as his persuase,
Is backed with reason and a rightful suit,
Physics first rule is this, as I have learned,
Kill the effect by cutting of the cause,
The same effects of ruffian outrages,
Comes by the cause of malice in your wines,
Had not they two been foes, you had been friends,
and we had been at home, and this same war,
In peaceful sleep had ne'er been dreamt upon,
Mother, and mistress Goursey to make them friends,
Is to be friends yourselves, you are the cause,
And these effects proceed you know from you,
Your hates give life unto these killing strifes,
But die, and if that envy ●ye in you,
Fathers yet stay, oh speak, oh stay a while,
Francis persuade thy mother master Goursey,
If that my mother will resolve your minds,
That 'tis but mere suspect, not common proof,
And if my father swears he's innocent,
As I durst pawn my soul with him he is,
And if your wife vow truth and constancy,
Will you be then persuaded?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Philip, if thy father will remit,
The wounds I gave him, and if these conditions
May be performed, I banish all my wrath.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And if thy mother will but clear me Philip,
As I am ready to protest I am,
Than master Goursey is my friend again.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hark mother, now you hear that your desires,
May be accomplished, they will both be friends
If you'll perform these articles.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: Shall I be friends with such an enemy?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What say you unto my persuase;

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: I say she's my deadly enemy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I but she will be your friend if you revolt.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: The words I said, what shall I eat a truth?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why hark ye mother.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mother what say you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Go.
sp.l: Why this I say she slandered my good name.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But if she now deny it, 'tis no defame.

sp.speaker: Mr Go.
sp.l: Why shall I think her hate will yield so much:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why? Doubt it not, her spirit may he such,

sp.speaker: M. Go.
sp.l: Why will it be?

sp.speaker: Ph●.
sp.l: Yet stay, I have some hope.
Mother, why mother, why hear ye,
Give me your hand, it is no more but thus,
'Tis easy labour to shake hands with her.
A little breath is spent in speaking of fair words,
When wrath hath violent delivered,

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What shall we be resolved?

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: O husband stay,
Stay master Goursey, though your wife doth hate me,
And bears unto me malice infinite.
And endless, yet I will respect your safeties,
I would not have you perish by our means,
I must confess, that only suspect,
And no proof else, hath fed my hate to her.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.l: And husband I protest by heaven and earth,
That her suspect is causeless and unjust,
And that I ne'er had such a vild intent,
Harm she imagined, where as none was meant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lo sir, what would ye more?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Yes Philip this:
That I confirm him in my innocence,
By this large universe.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: By that I swear, I'll credit none of you, until I here
Friendship concluded straight between them two,
If I see that they willingly will do,
Then I'll imagine all suspicion ends,
I may be then assured they being friends.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother, make full my wish, and be it so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: What shall I sue for friendship to my foe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, if she yield will you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ba.
sp.l: It may be I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why this is well, the other I will try,
Come mistress Goursey, do you first agree?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gour.
sp.l: What shall I yield unto mine enemy?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why if she will, will you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Perhaps I will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay then I find this goes forward still:
Mother give me your hand, give me yours to,
Be not so loath, some good thing I must do,
But lay your torches by, I like not them,
Come, come, deliver them unto your men,
Give me your hands, so now sir here I stand,
Holding two angry women in my hand,
And I must please them both, I could please tone,
But it is hard when there is two to one,
especially of women, but 'tis so,
They shall be pleased whether they will or no,
Which will come first? what both give back, ha, neither?
Why then yond may help that come both together,
So stand still, stand but a little while,
And see how I your angers will beguile,
Well yet there is no hurt, why then let me,
Join these two hands, and see how they'll agree,
Peace, peace, they cry, look how they friendly kiss,
Well all this while there is no harm in this,
Are not these two twins? twins should be both alike,
If tone speaks fair, the tother should not strike,
Jesus these warriors will not offer blows,
Why then 'tis strange that you two should be foes,
Oh yes, you'll say your weapons are your tongues,
Touch lip with lip and they are bound from wrongs,
Go to, embrace, and say if you be friends,
That here the angry women's quarrels ends,

sp.speaker: Mistress Gou.
sp.l: Then here it ends, if mistress barns say so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: If you say I, I list not to say no.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: If they be friends, by promise we agree.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And may this league of friendship ever be.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What sayest thou Frank, doth not this fall out well?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes if my mall were here, than all were well.

div.stage: Enter sir Raphe Smith with Mall.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Yonder they be mall, stay, stand close and stir not
Until I call: God save ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What sir Raph smith, you are a welcome man,
We wondered when we heard you were abroad.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Why sir, how heard ye that I was abroad?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: By your man.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: My man, where is he?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: O ye are a trusty squire.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: It had been better and he had said, a sure card.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why sir? Nic, because it is the proverb.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away ye ass.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: An ass goes a four legs, I go of two Christ cross.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hold you tongue.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: And make no mistake

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Go to, no more ado , gentle sir Raphe,
Your man is not in fault for missing you,
for he mistook by us and we by him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: And I by you, which now I well perceive,
But tell me gentlemen, what made ye all,
Be from your beds this night, and why thus late
Are your wives walking here about the fields?
'Tis strange to see such women of account,
Here, but I guess some great occasion,

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Faith this occasion sir, women will jar.
And jar they did today, and so they parted,
We knowing women's malice let alone,
Will canker like eat farther in their hearts,
Did seek a sudden cure, and thus it was,
A match between his daughter and my son,
No sooner motioned but 'twas agreed,
And they no sooner saw but wooed and liked,
They have it sought to cross, and cross it thus.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: F●e mistress barns and mistress Goursey both,
The greatest sin wherein your souls may sin,
I think is this, in crossing of true love,
Let me persuade ye.

sp.speaker: Mistress Bar.
sp.l: Sir we are persuaded,
And I and mistress Goursey are both friends,
And if my daughter were but found again,
Who now is missing, she had my consent,
To be disposed off to her own content.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: I do rejoice, that what I thought to do,
Ere I begin, I find already done,
Why this will please your friends at Abington,
Frank, if thou seekst that way, there thou shalt find
Her, whom I hold the comfort of thy mind.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: He shall not seek me, I will seek him out,
Since of my mother's grant I need not doubt.

sp.speaker: Mr Bar.
sp.l: Thy mother grants my girl, and she doth pray
To send unto you both a joyful day.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p: Nay mistress Barnes, I wish her better, that those joyful days may be turned to joyful nights.

sp.speaker: Coom
sp.p: Faith 'tis a pretty wench, and 'tis pity but she should have him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
And mistress Mary, when ye go to bed, God send
you good rest, and a peck of fleas in your nest, every one as big as Francis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well said wisdom, God send thee wise children,

sp.speaker: Nich
sp.l: And you more money.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ay, so wish I,

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: 'Twill be a good while, ere you wish your skinful of eyelet holes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Frank, hark ye? brother, now your wooings done,
The next thing now you do, is for a son:
I prithee, for i'faith I should be glad,
To have myself called nuncle and thou dad,
Well sister, if that Francis play the man,
My mother must be grandam and you mam,
To if Francis, to it sister, God send ye joy,
'Tis fine to sing dansey my own sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well sir on jest

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay fie, de you jest on.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Well may she prove a happy wife to him.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And may he prove as happy unto her.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Well gentlemen, good hap betide them both,
Since 'twas my hap thus hap thus happily to meet,
To be a witness of this sweet contract,
I do rejoice, wherefore to have this joy
Longer present with me, I do request
That all of you will be my promised guests,
This long night's labour doth desire some rest,
Besides this wished end, therefore I pray,
Let me detain ye but a dinner time,
Tell me I pray, shall I obtain so much.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Gentle sir Raphe, your courtesy is such,
As may impose command unto us all,
We will be thankful bold at your request,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I pray sir Raph, what cheer shall we have?

sp.speaker: Sir Raph.
sp.l: I'faith country fare, mutton and veal,
Perchance a duck or goose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O I am sick.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How now Mall, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Father and mother if you needs would know,
He named a goose, which is my stomach's foe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Come, come, she is with child of some odiest,
And now she's sick till that she bring it forth,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A jest quoth you? well brother if it be,
I fear 'twill prove an earnest unto me,
Goose said ye sir? o that same very name,
Hath in it much variety of shame,
Of all the birds that ever yet was seen,
I would not have them graze upon this green,
I hope they will not, for this, crop is poor,
And they may pasture upon greater store.
But yet 'tis pity that they let them pass,
And like a common bite the muse's grass,
Yet this I fear if Frank and I should kiss,
Some creeking goose would chide us with a hiss,
I mean not that goose sings it knows not what.
'Tis not that hiss when one says hist come hither,
Nor that same hiss that setteth dogs together,
Nor that same hiss that by a fire doth stand,
And hisseth T. or F. upon the hand,
But 'tis a hiss, and I'll unlace my coat,
For I should sound sure if I heard that note,
And then green ginger for the green goose cries,
Serves not the turn, I turned the white of eyes,
The rosa-solis yet that makes me live,
Is favours that these gentlemen may give,
But if they be displeased, then pleased am I,
To yield myself a hissing death to die,
Yet I hope here's none consents to kill,
But kindly take the favour of good will.
If any thing be in the pen to blame,
Then here stand I to blush the writer's shame.
If this be bad, he promises a better.
Trust him, and he will prove a right true debtor.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
